site_title: Bespoke Down Under
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Bespoke Down Under

Think you've seen it all in well-trodden Melbourne and Sydney? Whether you are just a couple or a big corporate group, Debbie Yong susses out 8 bespoke ways to experience the two Australian megacities

Published Fri, May 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Sydney

1 Explore the Sydney Opera House on a private tour

WHEN performances are not on-going at the opera house, glean interesting trivia behind the four performance spaces - the concert hall, opera theatre, drama theatre and playhouse - and the 10,000 pipes of the largest organ in the world on a private tour of the Unesco World Heritage-listed site. Did you know that the building's ship-inspired design by Danish architect Jorn Utzon was rescued from a pile of discarded early submissions? Or that its concert hall has played host to luminaries such as the Dalai Lama, the late Nelson Mandela and Arnold Schwarzenegger, who famously made his comeback in a bodybuilding competition held there in 1980? The performance halls and foyers can be cordoned off for corporate events and gala dinners, with professional opera singers rostered in if required. Or, take a cue from Australian tennis player Lleyton Hewitt and tie the knot under its eaves, with the sunset across the Sydney harbour bridge as a backdrop beyond compare.

Private tours in various languages, with additional packages for dinner, zoo visits or sailing trips available through

www.sydneyoperahouse.com

2 Sail across the Sydney harbour with a professional regatta crew

SNAPPING pictures of the opera house from the harbour bridge or vice versa too pedestrian for you? Dodge the general tourist scrum by setting sail across the harbour for unbeatable views of Sydney's most photographed icons. It's not just a leisurely cruise, mind you. You get to be part of the crew, helm the steering wheel or work on the grinders alongside veteran competitive sailors on your choice of two 75-ft yachts that have competed in prestigious sailing regatta, the America's Cup.

Private charters for 30 to 700 guests available through Sailing Sydney,

www.sailingsydney.net

3 Hog the Sydney Harbour Bridge for a private bridge climb

WHY jostle with the masses who only get in the way of your selfie on the very top, when you can have the bridge all to yourself as the ultimate bragging right? Besides the usual 3.5 hour or 2 hour express climbs for groups of 12 to 14, larger groups can also book the entire bridge for exclusive use at your preferred time, be it at sunrise, sunset or for special occasions such as New Year's Eve or wedding proposals. Capacity is not an issue: in July last year, over 2,100 climbers from Chinese firm Perfect China lodged a record for the largest group booking when they reserved the bridge for four days.

For private climbs and corporate packages, head to

www.bridgeclimb.com

4 Spend a day outdoors at outdoor adventure centre, Glenworth Valley

SYDNEY may be synonymous with the glittery big city lifestyle, but there are also activities aplenty in the great outdoors - if one knows where to look. Nearby Glenworth Valley is a popular outdoor adventure centre sequestered away in the hinterlands just 65km north of Sydney, and is an all-in-one stop for nature lovers looking to do some trekking, horse-riding, quad biking or camping under the stars.

There's a regular schedule of activities that kicks into high gear during the school holiday season, or send loved ones your wishlist for a bespoke itinerary. To truly get away in style, one can also opt to be shuttled between Sydney and the valley via a 20-minute helicopter ride, where you can take in panoramic views of Sydney and its surrounds.

For more information and schedules, visit

www.glenworth.com.au

Melbourne

1 Pad through the city on a guided walking tour

THE gold rush of the late 1800s meant that Melbourne was one of the richest cities in the world, hence elaborate turn-of-the-century architecture can still be spotted around the city today.

One place to see it all up close is The Block Arcade, a 19th-century shopping arcade dotted with storied boutiques such as Canturi Jewels by leading jewellery designer Stefano Canturi, who famously designed Nicole Kidman's 1,308 diamond-studded necklace in the movie Moulin Rouge! (2001), and the century-old Hopetoun Tea Room, which today pulls in a perpetual queue for its old-world three-tiered tea sets and pastries baked fresh daily.

A tip to skip the queue? The whole place can be booked out for private events and celebrations for a minimum sum. Later, explore the city's renowned laneways, a network of thoroughfares studded with quirky boutiques, with in-the-know locals from Melbourne Private Tours.

Though you're unlikely to lose yourself in the centre of the city, seasoned guides provide a much-needed compass to sniffing out gems, such as the legally permitted street art on Hosier Lane or Italian paper merchant Il Papiro and Clementine's, which specialises in produce sourced from around the Victoria state on Degraves Street.

Customised routes can be arranged through Melbourne Private Tours at

www.mpttravelandlifestyle.com.au

2 Brew your own Melbourne-style coffee

MELBOURNE is widely revered as a mecca for coffee - but don't just blithely drink it all in, learn how to brew up some black gold yourself too.

Author of Devouring Melbourne Monique Bayer has literally written the book on the origins of coffee in this foodie city, and also conducts food-centric tours around town, with hands-on coffee cupping classes included. If you're particularly good with your hands, you can pair this off with millinery and hatmaking workshops by expert milliner Kim Fletcher to fashion your own fascinator or fedora in time for the Melbourne Cup every November, the city's most glitzy excuse for dolling up.

Monique Bayer can be contacted through

www.walkmelbourne.com.au

and Kim Fletcher through

www.kimfletcher.com.au

3 View a musical or the Australian Open from a private suite

ALREADY caught the misbehaving tennis star Bernard Tomic stomping the courts at the Australian Open or a motorised King Kong puppet doing likewise in the Regent Theatre? Level up the experience by doing it again - but this time in a private hospitality suite.

Modern European pre-theatre dinner menus can be arranged at any of the Marriner Group's five landmark theatres, including the Regent, Princess and Forum theatres, in various plush, gilded rooms that can hold from 20 to 1,800 (the latter in the Regent's grandiose Plaza Ballroom). Because there's nothing like getting to beat the washroom queues and sneaking in a complimentary ice-cream during intermission.

Similarly, "superboxes" at the Rod Laver Arena can hold up to 18 persons and come with full food and wine catering, butlers, designated parking lots - along with a luxuriously air-conditioned bird's eye vantage point views of the tennis action.

Booking details for the Marriner group available at

www.marrinergroup.com.au

, and for the Rod Laver Arena's Superboxes at

www.rodlaverarena.com.au/superboxes

4 Explore the Yarra Valley

YOU haven't been to Melbourne if you haven't knocked back a glass in the Yarra Valley, Victoria's oldest wine region dotted with over 100 cool climate wineries.

For a winery with a difference, pencil in a refuelling stop at Rochford Wines, a 50 hectare property that is really more an entertainment venue comprising a winery, art gallery and restaurant next to 22 hectares of twisting grapevines.

Best known for hosting the A Day on the Green series of summer music concerts, which have seen the likes of Rod Stewart, Lionel Ritchie and Nora Jones performing onsite, the winery also regularly hosts jazz and other live music concerts throughout the year.

Bigger groups can opt to traverse its grapevines on Segways. There are also friendly archery, go-karting and wine stomping competitions that can be arranged for groups of up to 260 people.

Teetotallers or those with kids in tow can opt instead for a more contemplative saunter through stone fruit specialists Rayner's Orchard, where Farmer Len Rayner will truck you through his 25 hectare farm with 8,000 trees to sample everything from succulent peaches, persimmons and nectarines to rarely seen specimens such as the minuscule kiwi berries, Chinese quinces, strawberry peaches and pepinos, a succulent South America-originated cross between a melon, cucumber and tomato.

Trivia to impress your friends with: Did you know that the kiwi fruit is actually a Chinese gooseberry? It was named after the national bird of New Zealand in 1959 for being similarly small, brown and furry.

Later, cuddle up close with other Antipodean animals such as koalas and kangaroos at the nearby Healesville Sanctuary, part-educational zoo with plenty of activities for the young ones and part-bushland haven for wild animal rescue and rehabilitation. If you ask nicely, aboriginal elder-turned-part-time zoo attendant Murrindindi might even oblige with a one-on-one lesson on the finer points of playing the didgeridoo.

debyong@sph.com.sg

@DebbieYongBT

For more information, head to

www.rochfordwines.com.au

,

www.raynerstonefruit.com.au

and

www.zoo.org.au/healesville

Full convergence with IFRS slated for 2018

Move augurs well for Singapore as a financial hub

Listen to this article

Published Thu, May 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ALL Singapore-incorporated companies listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) will apply a new financial reporting framework identical to the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) in 2018.

The announcement, made yesterday by the Accounting Standards Council (ASC) which prescribes accounting standards here, has been lauded by some as timely, as it will make the financial reports of Singapore companies more comparable with those of their counterparts elsewhere.

"Singapore has long been an advocate of a single global financial reporting language," said ASC chairman Michael Lim in his keynote address at the IFRS Conference yesterday. "Taking the final leap towards full convergence with IFRS for our capital market is a decisive step towards cementing Singapore's standing as a trusted international financial and business centre."

site_title: CPF provides peace of mind: Chuan-Jin
content:
CPF provides peace of mind: Chuan-Jin

Lee U-Wen

Published

Thu, May 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Central Provident Fund (CPF) system may not be perfect, but it remains a valid system today, Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin said in Parliament yesterday.

There are trade-offs Singaporeans need to contend with, he said, given that the CPF system does not afford its members "full flexibility" in making use of their money - and with good reason.

"Ultimately, the CPF allows us to have peace of mind because you do have a constant stream of income at the point of retirement and it ensures that will continue, rather than you having to depend on someone else or the state," he told the House on the fourth day of the debate on President Tony Tan Keng Yam's recent address at the reopening of Parliament.

Over the week, several Members of Parliament have urged the government to do more to improve CPF returns; others have called for more alternative investment options to be made available.

Yesterday, Hougang MP Png Eng Huat of the opposition Workers' Party joined the debate, proposing a third CPF Life plan that gives a monthly payout from an early drawdown age of 60.

In his speech, Mr Tan noted that the CPF system has to cater to three main needs - namely housing, healthcare and retirement adequacy - so any move to allow CPF monies to be withdrawn earlier would cause concern.

"Ultimately, this is not about shifting risk to the people; it's about shifting risk to our children's generation," he warned. "The responsible thing to do may not always be the most popular, but to take into consideration these fundamental changes that are facing our society."

Not only are people living longer and working until a later age, Singapore has to deal with a smaller base of taxpayers in the future, the minister said.

As life expectancy goes up, the focus of the CPF system is to ensure that "we can live long, but we can live well as well".

One way to help people build their retirement kitty is to give them the option to work longer if they want to do so, he said.

"Raising the retirement age isn't about forcing people to work longer. If you don't want to, you can stop any time you wish. The fact of the matter is, we are living longer and staying healthier, and many people find working to be part of active ageing."

Mr Tan also spoke at length on some MPs' worries about whether the current rate of CPF returns was adequate, which he admitted was a "fair concern".

"Some have asked if CPF interest rates should be higher in order to withstand inflation. That's a fair consideration.

"Others have advocated higher returns, perhaps taking on more risk with CPF monies. But is that something we want to do?"

He noted that the existing CPF interest rates today are "far higher" than the equivalent rates provided by similar products in the market.

Still, he stressed, the government was studying this aspect in its plans to enhance the CPF Life annuity scheme, under which members receive payouts for the rest of their life.

On Wednesday, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong told the House that the government would look into improving the CPF and CPF Life schemes in such a way that the payouts would keep pace with the cost of living.

Lower-income groups who may not have very much tucked away in their CPF accounts would be given "stronger assurance" in retirement, he said.

Mr Lee will announce more details of the enhancements to CPF Life at his annual National Day Rally speech in August.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The right path for your heart

Besides price, there are also other considerations that the informed patient should look out for when making decisions on the use of heart services

Listen to this article

Published Fri, May 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN this Internet-connected society where information can be obtained at the click of a computer, there is an increasing trend for many services to be treated as a commodity where the main driver for decision-making is price. Healthcare services are not spared by this trend. Besides price, what else should the informed patient be looking out for in making a decision for the services best suited to his healthcare needs?

What you need to know about heart scans

This week Mr A, who is in his 50s, had chest pain for a few days and wanted to have a Computed Tomography scan of his heart arteries (also termed CT coronary angiography or CTCA) as he was concerned about the likelihood of heart artery disease. CTCA is a non-invasive outpatient procedure where an iodine-based contrast is injected into the arm veins and three-dimensional X-ray images of the heart arteries are taken within seconds. It is increasingly being used as an alternative to conventional coronary angiography (CCA) which involves the insertion of plastic tubes into the heart arteries to obtain images using X-rays. Over the last 10 years, the indications for the use of CTCA for the diagnosis of heart disease as recommended by the American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association have expanded rapidly to cover most areas of heart artery disease.

US shipyard enjoys new lease of life

Shale boom and Jones Act save historic Philadelphia Navy Yard

Listen to this article

Published Thu, May 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] The shale boom and the Jones Act are saving shipbuilding at the 213-year-old Philadelphia Navy Yard.

On a part of the grounds now operated by Aker ASA, workers apply a coat of gray paint to the deck of a new 800,000-barrel oil tanker in one dock. The hull of another tanker sits in the adjacent berth. Blue sparks fly from welding torches in the warehouse-sized shop where workers assemble sections known as grand blocks. Blue-green sheets of steel that will make up the skeleton of future ships are piled throughout the yard.

"Less than three years ago, you would have seen an empty dock, empty building dock, no grand blocks lying around and practically empty production halls," Kristian Rokke, the shipyard's executive chairman, said during an April 25 oil tanker christening ceremony at the shipyard. "Many were starting to say that we might not make it."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Another delightful opera evening in store

Published

Thu, May 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE ever-popular Singapore Lyric Opera's Opera in the Park is back for its seventh year, with an attractive line-up of singers and classics that include excerpts from Bizet's Carmen, Lehar's The Merry Widow, Puccini's Tosca and Wagner's Tannhauser.

The event has seen a surge in attendance since its inception in 2008 when it played to 4,000 people; last year, it was 20,000. This year, the organisers are hoping for even more to enjoy the evening at the Singapore Botanic Gardens.

Both familiar and new faces feature in the cast this time. Singaporean conductor Joshua Tan is back, and so are Singapore-born soprano Cherylene Liew and baritone William Lim.

This is the fifth Opera in the Park for Liew, who admits she is hooked on it: "I enjoy singing in such lush surroundings to a very appreciative audience."

Liew, who holds a Bachelor of Music (Voice) and Master of Philosophy in Music, will sing the second half of the programme: the Merry Widow segment. She is currently based in Brisbane, but has been commuting as often as she can.

As per tradition, the show will feature new faces, with three students from the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA) making their debut. Tenor Jeremy Koh, one of the trio, says: "It is my first Opera in the Park, but I look forward to singing outdoors for a change. The ambience is different from places like music halls."

Koh was recently awarded first prize at the Tan Ngiang Kaw/Tan Ngiang Ann Memorial Vocal Competition this year at NAFA.

In addition to the orchestra and lead singers, the Singapore Lyric Opera Children's Choir will also be making a guest appearance.

"I am a strong believer in opera being an accessible art form. Every Opera in the Park concert has been very well attended, so this is a great opportunity for me to help others get a taste of what opera is and could be," says Liew.

Opera in the Park' will be held on June 7 at 6pm, at the Shaw Foundation Symphony Stage at the Singapore Botanic Gardens.

Admission is free.

site_title: No deadline extension for OSG share sale
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

No deadline extension for OSG share sale

Shareholders have till June 3 to find buyer for their stock

Published

Wed, May 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[DELAWARE] Shareholders of Overseas Shipholding Group Inc (OSG), the largest owner of tankers that operate between US ports, lost a bid to extend the time that they have to sell their stock under a plan to reorganise the bankrupt company.

The judge overseeing the case denied the extension on Tuesday as he approved an explanation of the company's plan to exit bankruptcy by raising about US$1.5 billion in a share sale. That explanatory disclosure statement will be used by creditors and shareholders to decide whether to support the exit plan.

US Bankruptcy Judge Peter Walsh in Wilmington, Delaware, overruled an objection by a committee representing shareholders who wanted an extra five days to find a buyer for their stock. Under the plan, they have from now until June 3.

Small shareholders must choose between buying more shares as part of the new stock sale, accepting US$3 a share or trying to sell on the open market, where OSG has been trading at around US$6, the panel's lawyer, Steven Pohl, said in court on Tuesday.

Small shareholders do not have "the cheque book or the stomach" to keep their shares and buy more as part of the reorganisation plan, said Mr Pohl, a partner at Brown Rudnick LLP. "We seem like the only people standing up for the little guys."

More time would allow small, retail investors to sell their shares to the hedge funds and other investors that are sponsoring the new sale, Mr Pohl added.

OSG this month decided to pursue a reorganisation plan that provides a greater recovery to shareholders than its original proposal. A court-approved committee of shareholders convinced the company that raising about US$1.5 billion in an equity offering and about US$1.35 billion in exit financing was better than giving secured lenders ownership in exchange for debt.

OSG has the largest fleet of tankers operating under the Jones Act, which regulates shipping among US ports. It holds an exclusive permit to transfer oil from large ships to smaller vessels in Delaware Bay and operates the only two US flag shuttle tankers in the Gulf of Mexico.

The Jones Act requires that at least 75 per cent of OSG's equity be owned by US citizens, according to court documents. The reorganised OSG will craft bylaws to limit foreign ownership to no more than 23 per cent to comply with the law.

Investors holding about 30 per cent of OSG's stock have agreed to act as a safety net for the share sale, guaranteeing that the full amount is raised. The group has also agreed to buy about US$447 million more in other securities, according to court papers.

A group holding more than half of OSG's 7.5 per cent notes due in 2024 dropped its opposition to the plan last week after the company agreed to give them a piece of the share sale. The group agreed to buy as much as US$190 million to ensure that the full value is raised in the equity offering.

Under OSG's plan, shareholders that are accredited investors or institutional buyers would get subscription rights allowing them to buy 12 new Class A shares at US$3 apiece for each share of old stock, according to court papers.

Shareholders who do not qualify, or those who don't exercise their rights in the equity offering, would get a new Class B share for every one of their old.

OSG plans to halt trading in its shares on June 3, to determine who is entitled to participate in the offering, according to court filings.

The company, based in New York, fell 4.8 per cent to US$5.60 on Tuesday in over-the-counter trading. The shares dropped to as low as 42 US cents following the bankruptcy filing in November 2012. They have climbed since, peaking at US$9.87 on Jan 29.- Bloomberg

site_title: $1.2b govt IT tenders planned for this year
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

$1.2b govt IT tenders planned for this year

Published

Tue, May 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Smaller and more focused IT projects will feature prominently in this fiscal year's $1.2 billion worth of government infocomm tenders. The areas in which tenders will be called include cybersecurity, infrastructure, system development and maintenance, data and analytics, cloud and mobile services.

At the annual industry briefing on infocomm initiatives in the public sector yesterday, the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore's (IDA) Chan Cheow Hoe said the IDA would be looking at co-sourcing models where the industry would be partners in helping the government develop capabilities and solutions.

Mr Chan, who is IDA's assistant chief executive and government CIO (chief information officer), added that a multi-modal approach would used to accommodate innovation and to respond nimbly to complex demands for public services.

This year, 33 per cent of the tenders will be valued at between $200,000 and $500,000, and 22 per cent below $200,000. Out of the approximately 380 infocomm tenders that are likely to be awarded this year, 90 per cent will be valued below $5 million. This will mitigate risk and allow for faster completion of projects, according to IDA.

Jacqueline Poh, IDA's MD, observed that new technologies that emphasise speed and mobility are changing the way we live, work and interact with one another. "Likewise, citizen-centric services need to be rolled out in a more flexible and responsive manner - in keeping with these rapid developments." Singapore, in keeping with citizens' expectations, needs to provide services which are as easy to use and intuitive as, say, Twitter or Instragram, she added.

Ms Poh observed that while the $1.2 billion amount planned for this year was the same as that for last year, there would be significant differences in how the money would be spent. "We are looking to spend on initiatives that are progressive in nature. It will be done differently (this year), instead of large and chunky projects, tenders will be broken up into smaller ones."

She added that technology is moving at a very fast pace and people want to see the changes at lightning speed. "We can no longer wait for two to three years to see changes. The modular approach will give more opportunities to smaller companies in some of our projects."

She, however, added that the intention was not to circumvent governance requirements which would remain in place regardless of the size of the tender.

She mentioned the recently announced Accre-dition@IDA programme which accredits promising and innovative Singapore-based technology product startups to establish credentials and position them as qualified contenders to government and large enterprise buyers. These companies will also be able to bid for some of the tenders.

Mr Chan observed that the government would continue to invest in technology to enhance service delivery to citizens and businesses. A bulk tender exercise - which is part of the $1.2 billion tender amount - will see 12 companies providing agile software development services and three companies agile tools to all public agencies.

Agile software and tools refer to a development model that is based on iterative and incremental development where requirements and solution evolve through collaboration.

Mr Chan noted that this approach allowed system owners within the public sector to be more involved in the development process. Explaining the rationale behind the pre-selection of these vendors, he said that around eight to nine government agencies were looking at developing agile projects.

"Before, each would have done it separately and it would have taken six or seven months to get the project rolling and that would lead to some frustration.

"We have consolidated the needs together and said that as an estimate we are going to spend this amount during the year and pre-qualified a bunch of partners. Now, when the agencies are ready to call their tenders they can do so very quickly because all these partners are pre-qualified. This is an important first step to shorten the process while keeping the controls in place."

One example of a recent project created in an agile environment is the eCitizen Ideas! portal.

Apart from IDA, other government agencies also presented their infocomm procurement plans for this year. The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) will be investing more resources in areas such as video analysis, business analytics, modelling and simulation. The MHA will also continue to enhance or replace its existing operational systems.

The Ministry of Law and its statutory boards will be investing in their three-year ICT (infocomm technology) roadmap on 3D geospatial and integrated land information service.

The Ministry of Health noted that the majority of its planned IT investments for fiscal 2014 were in advanced stages of procurement.

S'pore firms take longer to close books: survey

Audit costs also higher; S'pore's role as regional HQ hub a possible reason

Published

Tue, May 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE companies take about one-and-a-half times longer to close annual and quarterly books and incur twice the audit costs compared to their global peers, according to a survey conducted by the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) and SAP for the accountancy sector.

The average Singapore company took 27.9 days to close annual books compared with 18.5 days for the average global peer.

Audit cost as a percentage of revenue for the average Singapore company was 0.12 per cent, compared with 0.06 per cent for the average global peer.

The Republic's role as a regional headquarters hub requiring consolidation of accounting and finance functions is a possible reason for the longer time taken to close books and higher audit costs, the survey found.

Said ISCA chief executive Lee Fook Chiew: "Compared to the best in class, Singapore finance departments have lower finance cost as a percentage of revenue. Companies seeking to reduce the number of days to close their books can choose to invest in technology as one of the ways to increase their efficiency."

The survey revealed that companies whose finance departments adopted best practices through technology achieved clear gains in overall productivity.

ISCA said companies that had a financial system capable of supporting internal and external accounting requirements took 30 per cent less time to close their annual accounts.

The results were obtained through an online and telephone survey between October and December 2013 and two focus groups in March and April this year.

ISCA said constraints were faced in terms of sample size as the survey marks the first attempt to obtain benchmarks of productivity indicators adapted from Spring Singapore's Integrated Management of Productivity Activities (Impact) framework.

In total, 221 professional accountants in business provided data for the accounting and finance functions in their companies from across industry clusters in manufacturing, retail and construction, among others.

The majority (59.9 per cent) of respondents were small and medium-sized companies with annual revenue of less than $100 million each.

The Singapore companies were compared to a global peer group in the SAP benchmarking database made up of 1,541 companies, with 41 per cent of them from North America and 27 per cent from the Asia-Pacific region.

Seventy-eight public accounting firms also responded to a separate component of the survey.

site_title: Fair-value gains boost Metro's Q4 bottom line
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Fair-value gains boost Metro's Q4 bottom line

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Wed, May 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BOOSTED by fair-value gains on investment properties, Metro Holdings posted fiscal fourth-quarter net profit of $43.8 million, almost three times that of $14.9 million a year earlier. This was despite a 97.3 per cent, or $8.3 million, fall in fair-value changes of short-term investments to $234,000.

Revenue for the property and retail group edged up 4.3 per cent to $49.7 million for the January-March final quarter due to higher rental income at Metro's property division, which saw turnover rise to $17.3 million from Q4 FY2013's $15.1 million.

Retail sales of its Singapore operations were nearly flat at $32.4 million in Q4 FY2014 vis-a-vis $32.5 million in Q4 FY2013 against the backdrop of a competitive retail environment and a shorter shopping period in the run-up to Chinese New Year this year. The retail division's associated company in Indonesia reported steady sales for continued stores, although the weaker rupiah and higher operational expenses hit profitability.

Gross profit for the quarter under review inched down from $19.92 million to $19.83 million as the property division had reported lower operational costs in Q4 FY2013.

The unrealised gain from fair-value adjustments on investment properties (excluding associates) registered $20.02 million - versus a deficit of $3.93 million for Q4 FY2013 - mainly due to higher valuations for EC Mall Beijing and other investment properties, offset by lower valuations of Metro City Shanghai and Frontier Koishikawa.

Share of associates' results contributed $18.05 million, compared to a loss of $2.03 million in Q4 FY2013. This was largely due to an unrealised gain of $20.4 million as compared to an unrealised deficit of $3.6 million in Q4 FY2013 from fair-value adjustments on investment properties of associates.

For the full year, net profit increased nearly 65 per cent to $106.85 million while revenue increased 3.82 per cent to $194.26 million. Earnings per share worked out to 12.9 cents, up from 7.8 cents.

The full-year results were helped by $40.5 million in fair-value gains from investment properties (including those held by associates), $29.6 million gain on disposal of a warehouse in Singapore and $19 million gain in negative goodwill on acquisition of an additional interest in the jointly controlled entities owning EC Mall in Beijing. Fair-value changes in short-term investments were a negative $5.3 million, against a positive $29.6 million in the preceding year.

Metro chairman Winston Choo said: "Our property division remains robust as we continue to expand Metro's footprint in China. The group will continue to seek new value-accretive business opportunities and add value to our existing portfolio of properties through asset enhancements to improve returns to shareholders."

The group has proposed a final dividend of two cents per share and a special dividend of four cents per share.

The counter closed at 98 cents yesterday, up three cents.

Lesser lights of 1990 show their class

NK YONG finds out how six non-First 1990 Bordeaux fare after almost a quarter century

Listen to this article

Published Thu, May 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT is in the DNA of human beings to keep striving upwards, focusing on the best, usually to the exclusion and neglect of the lesser lights, those below the Firsts and the Grand Crus. It is necessary to consciously and deliberately re-align one's horizons downwards.

I have recounted in previous columns the pleasure and delight provided by least expected wines, e.g. Vieux Chateau Certan 2007, Lynch Bages 2004 and many more. Their en primeur and current prices compared with the Firsts doubled the pleasure and enjoyment these "lesser lights" gave! An invitation, therefore, to dinner at which my host proposed a wine list of six non-Firsts 1990 Bordeaux wines was non-refusable. The wines: Chateaux Cos d'Estournel 2nd Growth St Estephe, Grand Puy Lacoste 5th Pauillac, Gruaud Larose St 2nd St Julien, Rauzan Segla 2nd Margaux, Magdelaine Premier Grand Cru Class (B), and L'Eglise Clinet, Pomerol. The only commune not represented was Graves.

1990 opened the decade with a bang, echoing the bang made by the 1989 vintage which closed the decade of the eighties. It was also the third of the great trilogy 1988-1990, a trilogy which aroused considerable debate: "Which of the three was the best?"

SUBSCRIBERS

One Raffles Place reopens today after major makeover

OUE shares rise 3.8% ahead of the mall's soft relaunch

Published

Wed, May 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] One Raffles Place shopping mall will reopen its doors today in a soft relaunch, after completing a major refurbishment exercise that gave it a new facade.

The mall, located just above Raffles Place MRT Station and with a net lettable area of about 98,500 square feet spread over six levels, has a committed occupancy of more than 90 per cent. Its tenants will progressively open for business, with Swedish clothing retailer H&M being the first to welcome shoppers today. The mall will also be introducing other new brands, such as Uniqlo, Victoria's Secret, Melissa and Paris Baguette.

"These brands, which are making their first foray in the area, bring a dose of Orchard Road into the heart of Raffles Place," said Letty Lee, retail services director of CBRE Singapore, the project's sole marketing agency. Other tenants include brands such as The Hour Glass, Tumi, Pandora, Swatch and Owndays.

One Raffles Place, formerly known as OUB Centre, is developed and managed by OUB Centre Limited. Overseas Union Enterprise (OUE) has a 40.8 per cent stake in One Raffles Place through its 50 per cent interest in OUB Centre Limited. Besides the retail mall, One Raffles Place has two Grade-A office towers. The 62-storey Tower One, at 280 metres, is among the world's 100 tallest buildings. The humbler 38-storey Tower Two office building opened in late 2012.

Earlier this month, when OUE announced its Q1 results, executive chairman Stephen Riady said the imminent completion of refurbishment works at the One Raffles Place mall and good progress of renovation at OUE Downtown will position the company to benefit from stronger recurrent income streams.

CBRE said the location where One Raffles Place is situated has a catchment of around 259,000 working professionals and PMEBs (professionals, managers, executives, businessmen) as well as about 10,700 international tourists in 2014, thanks to an increase in office space and hotel developments in the vicinity.

OUE shares closed nine cents, or 3.8 per cent, higher at $2.44 yesterday.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Etisalat given US$500m for Maroc Telecom deal

Grant is latest example of Abu Dhabi govt's support for local firms' foreign expansion

Published

Tue, May 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[DUBAI] Abu Dhabi gave Etisalat a US$500 million grant towards its 4.14 billion euro (S$7.1 billion) purchase of 53 per cent of Maroc Telecom, the company's prospectus for a planned bond issue shows.

The grant provides further evidence of Abu Dhabi's support for its companies' foreign expansion but could draw complaints from rivals about the Gulf emirate using its vast hydrocarbon wealth to subsidise state-owned businesses and distort competition.

Fellow Abu Dhabi-based company Etihad Airways benefited from a US$3 billion interest-free loan from the emirate's ruling family, the Australian Financial Review newspaper said last week, leading to complaints from rival airlines.

The Etisalat grant was mentioned in the prospectus for a bond issue to help to repay some of the debt the company took on to complete the Maroc Telecom transaction. "In connection with the acquisition, the group received an amount of US$500 million as a grant from an entity owned by the government of Abu Dhabi," the document stated.

Etisalat is 60 per cent-owned by the United Arab Emirates. The UAE is a federation of seven sheikhdoms, of which Abu Dhabi is the capital and holder of the vast majority of its oil reserves.

The grant comes on top of an 8.7 per cent stake taken by the Abu Dhabi Fund for Development - a state body which provides cheap loans and grants for projects in developing nations - in the legal entity that will hold Etisalat's Maroc Telecom stake.

Sources had told Reuters in April that Abu Dhabi was providing a quarter of the funding for the purchase of the stake from France's Vivendi, with the rest coming from bank loans.

Etisalat said last month that it had raised a 3.15 billion euro loan facility from 17 local and international banks, split between a 2.1 billion euro one-year bridging loan and a 1.05 billion euro three-year loan.

The bridging loan was always expected to be refinanced with a bond issue and Etisalat could start marketing that as early as next week, having chosen four banks to arrange the issue, four banking sources said.

It has chosen Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs, HSBC and Royal Bank of Scotland to arrange the euro-denominated offering, the sources added.

These four banks could be joined by others from among the company's lenders as "passive bookrunners", three of the sources said, although they added that Etisalat had yet to decide how many banks would be given such a title.

Under such a scenario, the main bookrunners take charge of running the bond sale to investors.

The passive bookrunners play little or no role, but both will be paid an arranging fee by the issuer, with the main banks usually receiving a greater sum.

The bond issue, should it materialise, will be Etisalat's debut offering and is expected to attract significant investor demand, given its rarity value and high rating.

In a rating report last week, which classified both the company and the bond programme as Aa3, Moody's said that Etisalat's rating was "amongst the highest for any rated global telecommunication service provider". - Reuters

site_title: A wake-up call for Europe's politicians
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A wake-up call for Europe's politicians

Published

Tue, May 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN the run-up to the European Parliament (EP) elections that concluded on Sunday, observers generally expected that extremist parties would make some gains. But hardly anyone forecast the dramatic results that we have seen, in which far-right parties have outperformed centrists in such large and significant EU members as France and the UK. The gains made by other extremist parties elsewhere were also far beyond expectations. The results have been described as a "political earthquake" and for understandable reasons.

In France, the National Front party led by Marine Le Pen, which has openly campaigned on a xenophobic agenda, won 25 per cent of the vote and topped the polls. In Britain, the UK Independence Party (UKIP) led by maverick politician Nigel Farage - who wants the UK to leave the European Union - did better than the mainstream Conservative, Labour and Liberal Democrat parties, picking up some 28 per cent of the vote. Far-right parties in Austria, Denmark, Hungary, Germany and Greece will also be sending their representatives to Brussels, as will the Greek far-left Syriza movement, which garnered more votes than the mainstream parties.

To be sure, centrists will still control the majority in the 751-seat European Parliament. Also, it is not clear to what extent, if at all, the extremist parties can collaborate with each other; they do not share the same agenda, and some are simply nationalistic. However, their presence will be noticeable and will make a difference. At a minimum, it will make EU-wide legislation a more protracted exercise. The ability of the EU to forge trade and other agreements with other countries and regions may also be complicated. In this context, the Singapore-EU free trade agreement will be coming up for a vote by the new Parliament; how smoothly it goes remains to be seen.

The unusual EP election results, even if surprising, are not hard to explain. Since 2008, the EU (especially the eurozone) has been through an economic wringer, with austerity programme after failed austerity programme foisted on hapless citizens by dithering politicians. Unemployment rates have soared and even now, after a recovery is claimed to be underway, are at around 25 per cent in Greece and Spain, and close to 12 per cent in the eurozone as a whole.

But it is not just the economically ravaged countries where extremist parties have gained; this has also happened in countries with relatively strong economies such as Germany, Austria and Denmark. This suggests a region-wide disillusionment with the way the EU has been run. There may be more pressure for decentralisation. Thus, initiatives such as a fiscal union and a banking union - which need more centralisation - may become harder to negotiate. On the plus side, the constituencies against austerity policies will be stronger. All told, Europe's mainstream politicians have been given a wake- up call to the effect that they must deliver rather than dither. And that is no bad thing.

[DONGGUAN, China] The days of rapid growth in China's real estate sector are over, but the government's urbanisation drive will continue to drive demand for the next 15 years, the country's biggest residential property developer China Vanke Co Ltd said.

After climbing at double-digit rates through most of last year, home prices in China started cooling in late 2013, with the annual growth in average new home prices slowing to an 11-month low in April as a sustained campaign to clamp down on speculative investment and easy credit gained traction.

site_title: SME development agency will provide a boost: McKinsey
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SME development agency will provide a boost: McKinsey

Published

Tue, May 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The need to ensure that Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have access to stable financing to ensure their growth and development, is not new. But global management consulting firm McKinsey & Company has taken the discussion a step further by giving details on gaps in SME financing and providing a comparative look at policies and experiences in other countries.

Notably, it has suggested in a paper the formation of an independent SME development institution in Singapore - possibly by combining various existing agencies - with the power to: raise capital like a company; extend different forms of financing like a bank; and still operate like a strategic SME development agency to develop targeted sectors or companies.

The paper, Perspectives on Building a more Sustainable Financial Services Sector in Singapore, looks at SME financing in particular, amid its general examination of the overall viability of Singapore's financial services.

It notes that SMEs represent a cornerstone of Singapore's economy - representing 99 per cent of all companies here, and contributing some 50 per cent of the country's gross domestic product. SMEs here also employ about 70 per cent of the workforce, comparable to most parts of Asia and other OECD countries.

Yet, despite their relative importance to the local economy, SMEs here are allowed to fail at a worryingly high rate - especially when compared with some other Asian countries. McKinsey noted that a 2011 DP Information Network survey of 2,500 Singapore SMEs found that nearly half fail within four years; that equates to a 12.5 per cent annual failure rate, compared with a 6.25 per cent failure rate in Korea and 6 per cent in Taiwan.

It noted that there were three types of SMEs here that struggle to obtain financing: small enterprises expanding overseas; small enterprises with trade relationships or businesses in distant emerging markets; and technology companies seeking to scale up.

"Global studies show that financing is a critical enabler of SME growth, particularly during times of economic crisis or restructuring," the McKinsey paper said.

Looking at case studies elsewhere in the world, McKinsey suggested three ideas worth exploring by Singapore to strengthen the sector:

Dr Teh Kok Peng, current chairman of Ascendas Pte Ltd and former president of GIC (Government of Singapore Investment Corporation) Special Projects - who provided the initial impetus for the paper - said in his foreword: "It is my impression that that there has not been a lack of schemes and initiatives over the years to help SMEs. However, their complexity, insufficient co-ordination and continuity and fragmentation have hindered their effectiveness. From a business perspective, a single independent agency, well-resourced and staffed, would help greatly to overcome these difficulties. It would be a focused learning organisation, in touch with, and adapting to, the changing needs of the SMEs."

site_title: Big financing demand from HNWIs
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Big financing demand from HNWIs

Credit Suisse's Q1 net new lending in Asia Pacific was 30% of its total loans in emerging markets

Genevieve Cua

Published

Tue, May 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ASIA's ultra wealthy may sit on tens or hundreds of millions of dollars in investible assets, but financing remains a key demand. Credit Suisse is finding that clients who are high net worth individuals (HNWIs) in Asia Pacific account for a disproportionate share of its emerging market private wealth management lending activity. That, however, is a measure of its success in the region, says Hans-Ulrich Meister, the bank's head of private banking and wealth management, and also a member of the executive board.

"When I see lending success in the first quarter, it's proof that we (have) shifted especially to the Asia Pacific, where there is a big need among the client base to have lending."

In Q1 this year, the bank's assets under management (AUM) in the Asia Pacific grew about 5 per cent to 121 billion Swiss francs (S$169.3 billion), from 115 billion francs at end-December, 2013. Asia Pacific accounts for about a tenth of the total group AUM of about 1.3 trillion francs.

However, in terms of net new lending to ultra high net worth clients in the emerging markets of 2.2 billion francs, the Asia Pacific's share was 30 per cent or 800 million francs. "That gives you an indication of what we are talking about: an overproportion of investment and commitment to this part of the world," he said. In 1Q13, net new lending came to 500 million francs.

The bank defines the ultra wealthy segment as clients with at least 50 million francs with the bank, or a net worth of 250 million francs. These clients account for over 60 per cent of its Asian AUM.

Mr Meister said the region is an important growth market. "We are highly committed to continuing to invest and grow our businesses in the region, and Singapore is where our largest private banking operations outside of Switzerland are based. Our private banking in Asia Pacific has done extremely well in building volumes in the last two years. More importantly, we have achieved it while significantly increasing our profitability, which provides us with a stronger base to continue to grow our business sustainably."

Credit Suisse had earlier said it would allocate a greater proportion of risk-weighted assets to its private bank and wealth management business to substantially increase lending.

Mr Meister, who spoke to BT recently, said: "When I look at the risk-weighted assets in the private bank, there is a clear shift to Asia Pacific, no doubt . . . Risk-weighted assets are a rare resource in today's banking world."

Head of private banking (Asia Pacific) Francesco de Ferrari said there are generally three types of lending that the bank extends to private clients. One is traditional lending with a liquid collateral. This is tapped by clients to reinvest and enhance yields.

A second is structured lending, which may be undertaken under a "Solution Partners" group with investment banking expertise. The services may include financing for large asset purchases or illiquid assets, and financial structuring such as risk hedging. Said Mr de Ferrari: "It works very well because the client comes with a need. We understand this client's need; we proceed to structure it. Then we go to the risk book that is most appropriate for this particular risk." A third type of lending is for real estate.

The bank, meanwhile, has also made strides in reducing cost. Cost-to-income ratio in wealth management stood at 67.7 per cent in the first quarter, down 5 percentage points compared to 1Q13.

Mr Meister said the bank has been "extremely successful" in its cost reduction programme. "We have a target till end of 2015 of 950 million (francs) in cost savings. We have now reached two-thirds at 630 million. This reflects our ability to achieve our cost-efficiency goals."

He believes that size remains an important success factor. "What is important is volume; you need size. Even if you hear differently from competitors, if you don't have the size, you will not really be successful . . . I am still convinced that if you have less than 50 billion in AUM . . . you will not survive."

He said clients still hold "quite a bit" of cash at close to 30 per cent. "This has to do with people's geopolitical assessment. They say even if cash is not an option in a low- interest environment, they hold cash." Clients, however, are investing in real assets such as real estate and classic cars.

"Generally, because of the low-interest environment, fixed-income products are not as attractive as they were. There is so much liquidity in the market. Generally, we are still quite clear you should overweight equities and all sorts of products linked to equities."

Meanwhile, Credit Suisse recently agreed to settle a United States tax dispute with a guilty plea and a payment of a US$2.6 billion fine. The bank has said that a conviction would not have a material impact on its operations.

Spanish property stabilises, mortgage approvals rise

Published Wed, May 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[MADRID] Spanish home mortgage approvals rose in March for the first time in almost four years, adding to signs that the property market is stabilising six years after triggering the worst recession in the country's democratic history.

The number of residential loan approvals rose 2 per cent from a year earlier, the first increase since April 2010, the Madrid-based National Statistics Institute said yesterday. The total amount lent rose by 16 per cent, its first gain since 2007. House prices in the country fell 3.5 per cent from a year ago in the first quarter, the smallest decline in over three years, separate data from the Public Works Ministry showed.

As a recovery in the fourth-largest economy in the euro area extends and its record unemployment subsides, the property market whose downfall locked the country into a six-year economic slump is showing signs of life. While home-price data isn't yet signalling a turnaround, improvements in sales and lending indicate that values may be starting to stabilise.

site_title: Indian PM gets off to a good start
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Indian PM gets off to a good start

Published

Wed, May 28, 2014 · 10:00 PM

INDIA'S new Prime Minister, Narendra Modi, is an outsider to the traditional power structure of the country and for this reason many expect him to bring in fresh ideas as head of the government. Mr Modi has, so far, lived up to this expectation. He engineered a diplomatic coup of sorts by inviting leaders of the Saarc (South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation) nations and Mauritius to his swearing-in ceremony on Monday. This is a first by an Indian prime minister. And it was not just a symbolic gesture: Mr Modi got down to serious talks with each of the leaders the next day.

India is a very important neighbour for all the countries and it was good that they got an opportunity to meet the new leader. The most important discussion Mr Modi had was with his Pakistani counterpart, Nawaz Sharif. He did raise Indian concerns about terrorism emanating from Pakistani soil but the thrust of the discussion was on trade. Both leaders have won their elections with landslide victories and are business-friendly. They have the mandate to transform the bilateral relationship into one driven by trade rather than politics.

Mr Modi has got off to a good start on this issue. Apart from this foreign policy foray, the first decision Mr Modi took was to announce the formation of a special investigation team to probe black money, most of which is stashed abroad. Some estimates reckon India's black economy is worth between 50 and 70 per cent of gross domestic product. Mr Modi's election slogan of minimum government and maximum governance has also resonated with the electorate. In keeping with this, he announced the smallest Cabinet that India has ever had. For synergy, he has clubbed related departments into one super ministry for better coordination. For example, road transport and shipping have been merged into one ministry, while urban development has been merged with housing and urban poverty alleviation. But while the start has been promising, it remains to be seen how Mr Modi and his team follow through. One of the problems the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party faces is a lack of experienced administrators. Navigating India's byzantine bureaucracy and getting things done can be a herculean task even for the most experienced leaders.

The other major challenge is reviving stalled economic growth. Mr Modi's win has been cheered by the business community, with India's stock indexes hitting historic highs as foreign funds flowed back into the country. However, this euphoria could be short-lived as there is no magic bullet to kickstart growth. India's slowdown from a peak of 9 per cent to less than 5 per cent is mainly due to a sharp drop in investment. A stable economic environment can help revive investment but it would still take three to four years for the effects to be visible and that too only if the global economic situation remains stable. How long Mr Modi's honeymoon period lasts is an open question. He must use his political capital wisely. His biggest challenge will be to ensure that the great expectations he has aroused in the Indian electorate are not quickly transformed into disillusionment.

site_title: Cut the VHF chatter, follow the rules!
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Cut the VHF chatter, follow the rules!

A recently launched guide says many investigations reveal VHF radio communication is a contributing factor in collisions at sea

Published

Tue, May 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

TOGETHER with shipping industry organisation Bimco, Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore have jointly published what is described as a "handy pamphlet for users of the Straits of Malacca and Singapore (SOMS)". It covers best practices to be observed, and the importance of keeping to the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (Colregs).

A statement announcing the pamphlet's launch noted that SOMS remains one of the busiest and most important shipping lanes in the world. It is a vital sea line of communication, carrying about one-third of the world's traded goods and used by ships voyaging from west to east. So not surprisingly, the publishers stress that "safety of navigation and the protection of the marine environment in the SOMS are of paramount importance".

In a perfect world, where all masters and watchkeepers knew the collision regulations by heart and always conducted their vessels in a seaman-like manner, there would be no need for a SOMS guide. It does contain some local information but in general it reinforces behaviour that should be deeply engrained in all professional mariners anyway.

Unfortunately, several recent incidents have highlighted the reality that we live in a far-from-perfect world.

Safe Passage: The Straits of Singapore and Malacca was officially launched at a meeting of the International Maritime Organization's Maritime Safety Committee, held in London. It is the result of an initiative pursued within the Co-operative Mechanism, a framework established in 2007 which the littoral states and users of the SOMS pool their respective resources and expertise in an effort to enhance navigational safety and protection of the marine environment in the SOMS.

The pamphlet advises on collision prevention measures, night signals for vessels crossing the Traffic Separation Scheme in the Singapore Strait, local rules for ships transiting the SOMS and on anchoring and weather conditions affecting visibility such as haze and heavy rain.

Again, there is little there that competent professional mariners should not know anyway. Nevertheless, this is a useful guide and one aspect is particularly welcome.

The pamphlet makes a point that needs to be hammered home to all watchkeepers throughout the world fleet. It says that many investigations worldwide have revealed that VHF radio communication is one of the contributing factors in collisions at sea. It notes: "In many of the so called 'VHF assisted' collisions, the 'VHF communication' between ships had created misunderstandings leading to close quarter situations or collisions."

It cautions: "Mariners are reminded that compliance with Colregs is a much more effective way to avert a collision than the use of VHF communications." That sentence cannot be repeated often enough at nautical colleges worldwide.

The dangers of using VHF as collision avoidance tool have been underlined yet again by a recent report from UK Marine Accident Investigation Branch (MAIB) of its investigation of the collision of the container ship CMA CGM Florida and bulk carrier Chou Shan in the East China Sea on March 19 last year.

As these two vessels approached each other, the Chinese watch officer on the bulk carrier called the container ship on the VHF radio. The VHF conversations were conducted in Mandarin and were not fully translated into English to enable the watchkeeping officer on one vessel to understand what had been tacitly agreed.

What had been agreed were alterations to port, contrary to Colregs. The MAIB has reminded the operators of both vessels that radio communications are not to be used as the sole or even the primary means for collision avoidance.

Unfortunately, calling up vessels and discussing an impending close quarters situation has become a widespread bad habit. It is one that the industry must give up.

[KUALA LUMPUR] Malaysia's government and British satellite firm Inmarsat yesterday released the data used to determine the path of missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, responding to mounting calls from passengers' relatives for greater transparency.

site_title: Baja Ferries in talks to buy ailing SNCM
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Baja Ferries in talks to buy ailing SNCM

Unishipping unit and Transdev discussing sale of 66% stake

Published

Tue, May 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[PARIS] US-Mexico ferry operator Baja Ferries is in talks with French transport firm Transdev about buying its 66 per cent stake in loss-making France-Corsica ferry operator SNCM.

Operator of a ferry line between Topolobampo, Mexico, and the city of La Paz on the Baja peninsula in California, Baja Ferries is part of Paris-based Unishipping, a privately owned shipping group which also operates a Puerto Rico-Dominican Republic ferry and has turnover of about US$160 million.

"Our proposal for SNCM seems well accepted by Transdev and was presented to the government," Unishipping chief executive Daniel Berrebi told Reuters on Monday.

Confirming the talks, a source close to Transdev said: "Unishipping is a serious candidate."

SNCM racked up cumulative losses of 250 million euros (S$428 million) between 2001 and 2013 and has made a small profit only once in the past decade.

Last year the government, which has a direct 25 per cent stake in the firm, gave the company 30 million euros to keep it sailing.

Norway's Siem Shipping earlier this month withdrew its bid for SNCM in a blow to environmental services group Veolia, whose Transdev unit - which it jointly owns with state-owned Caisse des depots (CDC) - has been trying for years to sell SNCM.

Transdev said on Monday it will propose logistics specialist Olivier Diehl, a former head of DHL France who has also run the French post office's Americas unit GeoPost, as the new SNCM chief executive at a board meeting today.

Mr Diehl, 58, is an expert in corporate restructuring and has roots in Marseille, a source close to Transdev told Reuters.

Following the dismissal of SNCM chief executive Marc Dufour - who had sided with the unions against his employer - Mr Diehl needs to put a new restructuring plan in motion and look for a buyer for SNCM.

SNCM's unions are wary of the new management and fear that Transdev will let the ferry operator go bankrupt.

"It looks like the highest levels of the French state, the prime minister and the president, have decided to abandon SNCM, despite the fact that solutions exist," CFE-CGC union representative Maurice Perrin told Reuters on Monday.

The transport ministry was not immediately available to comment.

Veolia has said the firm needs to go under court protection to shield itself from a European Union order that it repay 440 million euros of illegal state aid.

A source with direct knowledge of the situation told Reuters that as bookings for the summer season come in, SNCM should have enough cash to pay salaries and fuel in coming months.

Barring the unforeseen in the summer, SNCM should have no liquidity problems in the short term, he said. - Reuters

GE hopes CFM venture will boost its bid for Alstom

Published Tue, May 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[VILLAROCHE, France] In a cavernous factory planted in farmland here south of Paris, workers assemble the best-selling aircraft engine in history, in a feat of trans-Atlantic industrial cooperation that has few parallels.

Engineers and technicians in blue overalls carefully marry US-made engine cores - each containing a combustion chamber and related elements - to French-made turbofans, turbines and compressors. Combined, they form jet engines weighing 2½ tonnes each.

Every month, up to 65 of these powerful machines are borne by a series of yellow cranes through assembly and testing stations before being shipped out for mounting on the wings of the world's most popular passenger jets.

site_title: Seadrill to be top owner of North Atlantic Drilling
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Seadrill to be top owner of North Atlantic Drilling

Published

Tue, May 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[OSLO] The world's largest offshore driller, Seadrill, will remain the majority owner in North Atlantic Drilling, board member Tor Olav Troeim said, after news at the weekend of a cooperation deal with Russia's Rosneft.

On Saturday, Russia's largest oil company and North Atlantic Drilling, a rig firm controlled by shipping tycoon John Fredriksen, announced they would work together drilling oil and gas fields in Russia until 2022.

The deal is a coup for Mr Fredriksen, nicknamed "Big Wolf" for his business instincts, as it gives him access to the Russian market on a large scale. For Rosneft, it is an affirmation of the keenness of multinationals to do business with Russia, despite tensions over the crisis in Ukraine.

"Seadrill will remain the majority owner in North Atlantic Drilling. We have not thought about selling any shares. We have 70 per cent today," said Mr Troeim, a Seadrill board member, adding the firm intended to retain a majority stake "for a long time".

Mr Troeim made the comment after Rosneft boss Igor Sechin said his firm could take a stake of up to 50 per cent in North Atlantic Drilling over time. "We are even more optimistic about the company's future after signing this deal."

The deal, which would involve using onshore and offshore rigs in Russia until 2022, would initially deploy up to nine offshore rigs for an overall commitment of 35 rig years, Seadrill said on Monday.

"Seadrill again pulls something extraordinary out of the hat," Fearnley Securities said in a note to clients. "This is extremely positive. There are few details about how the contracts are set up and how the ownership structure will be. But for me and the market, this is a positive surprise," said Kristoffer Riis Iden, an analyst at Arctic Securities in Oslo.

None of the companies said how much the deal was worth but Mr Troeim said the deal was a "game changer" for North Atlantic Drilling, which specialises in drilling in harsh offshore areas.

"When Rosneft goes into the firm the idea is that this will be turned into an offshore company that will to a great degree serve Rosneft, which produces five million barrels a day and has activities worldwide," said Mr Troeim.

He did not expect sanctions placed on Mr Sechin by the United States in response to the Ukraine crisis to affect the deal, even though Seadrill is also listed in the US, as well as in Oslo.

"We will of course comply with international sanctions," he said. "At the same time, this is a deal that was initiated long before the issue (of sanctions) became a topic and that will hopefully last long after a solution has been found."

Separately, Mr Troeim said he did not expect the market for rigs, which has declined slightly recently, to fall further.

"I am of course respectful of the fact that the market, in the short term, can be characterised by higher supply than demand, but I am not especially worried," he said.- Reuters

site_title: Japan-China economic ties not affected: economist
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Japan-China economic ties not affected: economist

It's business as usual for Japan's firms in China despite rising political tensions

Published

Mon, May 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] It seems pretty much business as usual for Japanese businesses in China despite a heightening of tensions between the two countries, said a senior economist at The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ.

"Economic relationship is not so influenced by political relationship," said Hayato Nakamura of the bank's economic research office (Singapore).

He was answering questions following a media briefing on the prospects and challenges of the Japanese economy.

Over the weekend, Japanese Defence Minister Itsunori Onodera said Chinese fighter jets had reportedly come within 30 metres of a Japanese Self-Defence Forces (SDF) aircraft over the East China Sea.

Two SDF aircraft were monitoring a joint naval drill by China and Russia in the sea near Japanese territorial waters when the incident occurred on Saturday, a Japanese government source was reported by Kyodo news service as saying. Japan immediately lodged a diplomatic protest with China.

China's Defence Ministry reported on Sunday that the country's military scrambled fighter jets on Saturday in response to Japanese SDF aircraft entering an air defence identification zone that China had unilaterally established over the East China Sea last year.

The incident came just days after Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong had warned in a speech in Tokyo that such "incidents can escalate and miscalculations can lead to unintended conflicts", a concern that was echoed by former Malaysian prime minister Mahathir Mohamad.

China was Japan's second-largest investment destination in Asia last year. In 2013, Japanese investments in China totalled 0.88 trillion yen (S$10.8 billion), down from 1.07 trillion yen in 2012, Bank of Japan (BOJ) data showed.

On Japan's economic prospects, Mr Nakamura said recovery in the world's third-largest economy was steady and there was enough momentum to overcome the consumption tax hike. In April, Japan hiked its consumption tax to 8 per cent from 5 per cent.

"Abenomics", or the stimulus measures of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, is working, leading to more investments by corporates and households as salaries rise, he noted.

"Japanese corporate profits are at a historical high now, the labour market is tight . . . (we) think Abenomics will work," he added.

Growth in 2014, which will be dented by the consumption tax hike, is still likely to be positive, at 1.2 per cent, after last year's 2.3 per cent.

For Q2 2014, the economy is forecast to fall to minus 4.7 per cent as consumption tumbles following April's sales tax hike, but it is likely to recover subsequently, supported by higher wages and more stimulus measures from the BOJ, he explained.

site_title: Ser Luck assures SMEs on economic transition
content:
Ser Luck assures SMEs on economic transition

Govt will give all the help they need during this period

Lee U-Wen

Published

Mon, May 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The government recognises that the ongoing economic transformation is a difficult transition for many to navigate, especially the smaller businesses out there.

Companies, however, will get all the assistance they need to get through this period, said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Teo Ser Luck in Parliament yesterday.

"We are committed to providing strong support for SMEs (small and medium-sized enterprises) during this transition," he said on the first day of the debate on President Tony Tan Keng Yam's recent address to the House.

Mr Teo spoke of how the government would try to make its schemes and programmes both accessible and inclusive.

It will also facilitate collaboration with large organisations to help SMEs gain experience, improve their quality of goods and services, and develop a track record, he said.

On the issue of manpower, which Mr Teo recognised was a "fundamental constraint" for Singapore, he noted that it was not possible to grow the country's workforce indefinitely.

SMEs, therefore, need to adapt and push for higher productivity in order to bring about sustainable and quality growth.

While many companies have been successful on that front, the government will continue to help SMEs boost their productivity, said Mr Teo.

More than half of the $2 billion National Productivity Fund has already been committed to date, with much of this going to SMEs.

The Ministry of Trade and Industry has also set aside over $300 million for the next three years to support SMEs in restructuring.

Beyond funding, the government will continue to ensure that government schemes are accessible, simplify grants and application procedures, and expand the network of SME centres, said Mr Teo.

With SMEs employing 70 per cent of the country's workforce, these companies have a crucial role to play in the government's effort to prepare Singaporeans for specialist, managerial and leadership roles in the economy.

"SMEs need well- trained and talented Singaporeans in their companies. They need motivated Singaporean workers who can find meaning in their work, and will help take our SMEs to the next level," said Mr Teo, adding that the government would help SMEs to be "employers of choice".

While the government will work with trade associations and business chambers to match graduating students to SMEs, he said that the companies themselves must ensure they are attractive employers.

They have to put in place good compensation packages, have good human resource practices and plan a rewarding career path for their staff, said Mr Teo.

On its part, the government was ready to support SMEs by helping them to access the required expertise and revamp their approach to talent management.

Given the small size of Singapore's economy, he made the point that businesses here should serve not just the domestic market but the rest of the world as well.

SMEs, said Mr Teo, should ride on the growth of Asia, as well as the continued recovery in the United States and Europe, to seize growth opportunities.

The government will also expand its network of free trade and investment guarantee agreements to help businesses export and invest overseas.

"This is critical because Singapore is small and many of our businesses need to serve the international market to grow and thrive," said Mr Teo.

site_title: AirAsia's low-cost model 'won't work in India'
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

AirAsia's low-cost model 'won't work in India'

Malaysian budget carrier to increase load factor to 85%, rationalise fleet

Published

Mon, May 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

A SENIOR aviation industry official in India has rubbished claims that AirAsia's Indian operations can offer cheaper fares than the rest of its competitors.

The Economic Times quoted Sanjiv Kapoor, chief operating officer of low-cost Indian operator SpiceJet, as saying over the weekend that AirAsia's low-cost model would not work in the country in the face of high costs.

"There is only one way to offer fares lower by 30-35 per cent than market rates, and that is to have a 30-35 per cent lower cost structure," Mr Kapoor was quoted by the Indian newspaper as saying. "Given fuel and other costs are similar for all players in India, that kind of cost advantage can only come from lower aircraft and asset costs. You can have that kind of cost advantage if, maybe, part of your costs are reflected in Kuala Lumpur and not in India."

Mr Kapoor was referring to a recent claim from AirAsia-India chief executive Mittu Chandilya that the airline would offer "dramatically" lower fares once it begins operations in the country from its headquarters in Chennai.

In a tweet early last week, AirAsia chief executive Tony Fernandes disclosed that New Delhi had finally granted his airline a licence to operate in India. He also told reporters that AirAsia-India would probably start operations in the third quarter of the year.

Its licence was delayed by over a year after protracted resistance from local Indian airlines fearful of increased competition.

Indian carriers, including SpiceJet, are bleeding from high input costs, primarily fuel prices, borrowing rates and dollar-denominated purchases amid a depreciating rupee.

Put together, all airlines operating in India registered a combined loss of US$300 million as at September 2013, according to the Federation of Indian Airlines (FIA). When AirAsia first applied for a licence to operate in India, the FIA objected, saying it feared that the entry of the new airline would cause the industry to incur further losses.

New entrants keep coming into the country, anyway. AirAsia and Singapore Airlines have both tied up with Tata Group for separate ventures, while Abu Dhabi's Etihad Airways has bought a stake in Jet Airways after New Delhi eased investment rules in 2012, all of them eager to tap the potential of a 1.2 billion population.

Mr Fernandes, meanwhile, seems blithely sanguine about his prospects. Following years of expansion and franchising, his airline plans to increase its load factor to 85 per cent (from 81 per cent presently) and rationalise its fleet through aircraft sales.

"These next two years, we have the ability to enter up to 85 per cent," Mr Fernandes was quoted as saying by Malaysia's The Star newspaper. "We see growth opportunities in the Philippine, Indian and Japanese markets."
