site_title: Tapping into AEC's free flow of resources
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tapping into AEC's free flow of resources

What would be the impact of an Asean Economic Community in 2015 on your industry? How is your organisation gearing up to ride the market opportunities?

Published Sun, May 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Chaly Mah

Chairman of Deloitte Singapore and

CEO of Deloitte Asia Pacific

THE AEC is a journey that will unfold over time. It is not, as many believe it to be, a ''Big Bang''. Much has been done on the regulatory front but the changes are not yet fully understood by the business community.

The imperative now is for businesses to consider and implement the strategic and operational choices that will become possible with the creation of a trading bloc with a population of some 600 million, with free flow of skilled labour, services, investments and capital.

Winners will adopt a broader mindset and transform their thinking from competing within national boundaries to winning on a regional basis.

We urge governments to press forward with a stepped implementation in 2015 rather than wait for all member states to be fully prepared. By creating an integrated Deloitte South-east Asia firm in 2006, we can easily leverage our regional platform to deploy our resources across all markets to help our clients tap the opportunities presented by the AEC.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

PLAN-B ICAG Pte Ltd

THE Asean Economic Community (AEC) can benefit many industries when it truly can result in a freer flow of people, products and services, compared to the status quo. It would be an added boon when the financial and banking industry is deregulated as well, so that more foreign banks can be set up in host countries. This will facilitate trade immensely. Organisations gearing up to ride the market opportunities will need to increase their local presence.

I will prioritise the countries where I would want to increase my direct investments and presence in. For the other countries, I will look at establishing distribution channels. Health care is one industry that I have been focusing on in recent years, in particular, telehealth consulting services for triage management, chronic disease management, wellness management, care for the aged and help for caregivers.

I hope that with the establishment of the AEC, it would be easier for me to set up cross-border call centres, which can mutually support one another in the larger Asean framework. This will help me tackle the manpower shortages, especially of qualified nurses, and the higher costs of operations in Singapore.

Businesses will still have to pay particular attention to country and political risks when embarking on any expansion plan in the AEC. Such risks can erode any economic benefits derived from the AEC. A case in point is the recent attacks on Chinese factories and firms in Vietnam, arising from the dispute between China and Vietnam over territorial rights in the South China Sea. Businesses will just have to be mindful that if there is one show stopper in the AEC, it would be country and political risks. In this regard, many lessons can be learnt from the European Community.

Chris Comer

CEO

Castlewood Group

THE impending Asean Economic Community is an exciting time for the 10 nations involved. Not only does it allow us to work as a single market and become more competitive, but it will enable the region to act together with the global economy combining 600 million people divided by various languages, religions, political agendas and economic standings.

Since the global economic crisis, investors have looked to Asia - which remained relatively unscathed - as an investment haven. For both international and local investors there will be rewards as the anticipated economic growth and integration of capital markets will help generate higher yields and increased capital appreciation on real estate investments.

The Asean Economic Community will most certainly give businesses a number of advantages to drive forward with future development plans. For instance, for Castlewood Group as a property developer we should see a considerable reduction in the price of construction equipment, and transportation, labour and transaction costs. At the same time, there will be an increase in overseas investment into the region as investors try to capitalise on the rise of South-east Asia. Increased competition across the market will drive productivity, which should also help to drive down costs.

The newly formed community will also present us with more opportunities to further expand our operations into neighbouring countries. While there will be a number of development opportunities for us, we must also take note that the free market will allow skilled labour to move freely across markets. This means that while we will have access to a larger pool of labour, we might also lose some of the skilled workers we have come to rely on.

It is vital that all potential impacts, both positive and negative, are assessed and contingency plans put in place prior to the launch of the community. It is not only the respective governments' responsibility to identify the impact but also for each individual firm to assess the potential implications on their business.

The introduction of the community has long-term benefits but its implementation will not be without teething problems; we have to remember that there are 10 different countries, representing different cultures and attitudes. Resolving internal conflicts or difficult issues will challenge the unity of the community, but we must remain vigilant and open-minded to ensure that we tackle them in the best way we can.

Stuart Green

CEO Asia Pacific

Interbrand

WITH the AEC launching in 2015, we are seeing many organisations preparing their businesses from an operations perspective but perhaps not giving enough thought to the opportunities and challenges for their brands. The AEC will lead to tougher competition, short-lived competitive advantage, and therefore an increase in the brand's contribution to shareholder value. For those that seize the opportunities, the brand is one of the few business assets that can provide long-term differentiation and impact business performance.

Strong brands influence customer choice and create loyalty; attract, retain, and motivate talent; and lower the cost of financing. Well-managed brands create ongoing demand, allowing their owners to enjoy higher returns and mitigate risks. This strikes me as directly supporting the very objectives of the AEC.

Interbrand has a diverse range of insightful thinkers bringing together a combination of rigorous strategy and analytics with world-class design creativity to help its clients create and manage brand value in all market dynamics. We hope to work with our clients in Asean to help them be prepared for the opportunities that the AEC may bring in 2015 and beyond.

David Crammond

Founder & CEO

Maachu Pte Ltd

GENERALLY, an Asean Economic Community in 2015 will create greater market opportunities for most businesses. The establishment of AEC is set to eliminate trade barriers, facilitating the free flow of goods, services and capital within the bloc.

North America went through a similar process with the creation of Nafta many years ago. The creation of an integrated single market will also have a major impact on the mobility of talent. This relates to our business at Maachu which aims to bring the best talent to employers and likewise the best opportunities to candidates.

However, we have to acknowledge that this may be one of the most challenging aspects of AEC that the governments need to grapple with. To encourage trade and investments, there needs to be ''liquidity of talent''. Governments will need to manage this proactively as investments cannot flow freely without a corresponding increase in the ''liquidity of talent''.

Joseph Lim

Vice-President, Asia Pacific

FNT Software

THE impending transformation of South-east Asia into the Asean Economic Community next year comes some 13 years after the European Union became one common market. Eight years after German headquartered FNT Software operated as a corporate entity in individual European markets, the union transformed the geography into a single market and production base, with free movement of goods, services, investment, skilled labour, and freer flow of capital.

On hindsight, despite the trials and tribulations of the EU, as a union, we know that there has been a lot of give-and-take in the interests of the union's betterment. This has benefited the IT industry and others and similarly it should for Asean.

FNT Software is a relatively new entrant to the Asian market and from where we came, we view the establishment of the common union market as a crossing of a major bridge in a long journey. One area where the European economy has benefited from the integration is in the area of data centre infrastructure management, a specialised area which will come to bear as South-east Asia becomes a common market. In this regard, we view Malaysia and Indonesia as promising opportunities.

Rick Scurfield

Senior Vice-President and General Manager

NetApp, Asia Pacific

WITH the formation of the AEC, South-east Asia stands to become a bigger player in the global economy. We can expect a proliferation of start-ups as well as rapid growth across sectors such as banking, manufacturing and telecommunication. With the advent of the AEC, we anticipate that governments will also invest heavily in building both physical and technological infrastructure to ensure their nations have a competitive foothold in the new marketplace.

Developing nations and small businesses may even leapfrog their more technologically advanced counterparts with the adoption of cloud and other cutting-edge solutions that will help them challenge more established players in the AEC.

The common market will bring tremendous opportunities for businesses and it is important for companies to collaborate with experienced technology providers that can assist in designing and building the right technology architecture, whether the information resides in the cloud or on premise.

Kenneth Arredondo

President & General Manager, Asia Pacific & Japan

CA Technologies

THE Asia Pacific region, including Japan and particularly South-east Asia, is one of the most dynamic regions of growth for CA Technologies globally. If we look at the 10 countries that make up Asean, we see diversely different markets governed by their own sets of economic policies and regulations.

But if we look at Asean as a single economic entity, it would rank as the world's eighth largest economy with a largely-young population base of 600 million people. I strongly believe that the Asean Economic Community will unlock the full growth potential of the region, enabling businesses within and from outside Asean to thrive in a diverse area now united by principles of free trade.

The AEC framework will enhance the flow of talents and technologies in the IT industry, allowing global IT companies like CA to better serve the region with greater uniformity and economies of scale. Ultimately, this means that CA will be able to launch new technologies and expand our presence much faster across the region.

With AEC in place potentially in 2015, we hope to accelerate the expansion of our reach across Asean markets from our regional headquarters in Singapore, enabling our software to help nations and businesses drive greater competitive advantage in this application economy.

Ravi Rajendran

Vice-President & General Manager, Asean & India

Hitachi Data Systems

THE biggest opportunities created by the AEC are two-fold for Hitachi Data Systems: Firstly, as it becomes easier for businesses to expand across the region, companies will turn to seamless technologies to improve connectivity, manage data growth and enhance information flow across the region. Secondly, the AEC will create a more integrated region, presenting opportunities for sharing of ICT best practices, innovation and talent across the region, ensuring that Asean becomes more competitive on a global scale as enterprises aim to leverage technology to outpace their competitors.

Together with our parent company, Hitachi, we have engaged as ONE Hitachi to build our social innovation vision that lays the foundation for the future growth markets. As enterprises will depend on information innovation to drive their businesses in Asean, we will continue to be their strategic partner to create solutions that address real-world growth challenges the region will face in 2015.

Nando Cesarone

President, South Asia District

UPS Asia Pacific

UPS believes that free and open trade drives business and economic prosperity, and the 2015 Asean Economic Community, when fully enacted, is an exciting opportunity for the logistics industry. Customers will greatly benefit from the reductions in trade barriers, allowing for a more seamless movement of goods in the region.

We anticipate that greater transport connectivity will open up new cross-border routes that will ultimately create efficiencies and lower operational costs. Companies will be able to expand their market reach and to start doing business with customers across previously inaccessible markets. UPS stands ready to take advantage of these opportunities as Asean works towards liberalising the logistics industry, a move that will raise overall competitiveness across all industry sectors.

Neeraj Swaroop

Chief Executive Officer, Singapore

Standard Chartered Bank

ASEAN is on a path of economic convergence. While this may be more of a journey than an end, the growth of investments and trade, an expanding middle class and burgeoning consumerism in the region have also led to the creation of wealth.

More importantly, at Standard Chartered, our role is to help our clients further their personal and business ambitions. A common market would present enormous opportunities for them to grow their wealth and business across Asean. We are well-positioned to help our clients tap these opportunities because we have a history of more than 150 years, close to 400 branches and over 30,000 staff dedicated to serving them in this region. We are also the only international bank to have a presence in all 10 Asean markets.

Recently, we sharpened our focus via a bank-wide realignment to an eight-region geographical structure, of which Asean is one. This new structure gives special emphasis on the way we support and serve our clients and allows us to leverage the growing economic and commercial collaboration in the region. Singapore is central to the opportunities in Asean and we will continue to leverage it as a gateway to the region and wider Asia to facilitate trade and investment flows across our footprint of Asia, Africa and the Middle East.

Max Loh

Country Managing Partner

Ernst & Young LLP

THE promised free flow of goods, services and people in an Asean Economic Community will open up unprecedented opportunities - and a ''steep learning curve'' - for businesses and the professional services industry. The ability to serve the varying needs of businesses - inbound, outbound and within Asean - seamlessly across geographies will be critical.

To that end, EY has integrated its practices worldwide, with Asean being one of its integrated operating regions since 2008. This enables us to tap a widened and more mobile talent pool to bring global experience and local knowledge together to serve the needs of clients.

As much as the AEC brings forth opportunities for collaboration, there will be heightened competition among businesses, amid continued complexities of navigating markets at varying levels of economic maturity.

Such is the vibrancy of the Asean region that the professional services industry must keep innovating itself, while its practitioners must have strong technical knowledge and expertise as well as a deep appreciation of regional, if not international, cultural and business norms and nuances in order to succeed.

Reto Brosi

Chief Executive

Asia Capital Reinsurance Group Pte Ltd

OVER time, the establishment of the AEC will open up new opportunities for everyone, with faster and more efficient access to new markets. Customer service can and will have to expand across multiple territories rather than just within the domestic market. There will also be an innovation boost due to the easier flow of new production and related technologies across countries within the region.

For the (re)insurance industry, the AEC will mean both a risk management opportunity as well as challenge. The opportunities to help clients adapt to new risks in the common market will pave the way for more innovative products and services covering multiple jurisdictions; at the same time, it also means that risk bearers will be more exposed to the dynamics of this greater interconnectedness.

Multinational (re)insurers will have a head start in terms of innovation and managing the issues of cross border business. The more 'local' (re)insurers, however, have the advantage of strong domestic distribution access, which they must leverage strongly.

Mark Newman

CEO

ING Commercial Banking Asia

THE Asean Economic Community has the potential to present the region as an attractive common market for foreign investments and business opportunities. ING Bank is positive about the economic upsides that the community can bring.

That said, there can be lessons learnt from the European Union experience. The bottom line is that the AEC would benefit greatly by adopting a pragmatic approach based on Asean's current and envisioned market position.

In banking, the establishment of the AEC by 2015 would present an opportunity to have a united and stronger voice towards managing extraterritorial regulations from Europe and the US on the financial markets. Additionally, the banking industry would greatly welcome a common approach towards clearing services and trade reporting which will significantly reduce the cost of establishing multiple clearing houses in the 10 member-states.

Yeoh Oon Jin

Executive Chairman

PwC Singapore

THE setting up of the Asean Economic Community in 2015 holds great promises for Singapore. Ninety-six per cent of Asean CEOs who responded to the recent PwC 17th Annual Global CEO Survey expressed optimism of high growth in Asean. Asean is a natural market with a sizeable population of 600 million or 9 per cent of the world's population. As a single entity, the AEC will be the world's 8th largest economy.

In PwC, we have been providing high quality and seamless service to our clients who operate across the region. The formation of the AEC will present more opportunities for us to provide regional advice in the areas of tax, deals and consulting. PwC will continue to bring in the right resources and expertise to serve our clients across industries and the region. PwC is proud to join hands with others in the profession on a journey to shape Singapore into a regional accounting hub which has added importance with the formation of the AEC.

Herbert Vongpusanachai

Managing Director

DHL Express (Singapore)

REDUCTION in cross-border regulations, elimination of tariffs and freer movement of goods are just some of the benefits that the Asean Economic Community will bring in 2015. This will create a conducive environment for SMEs in Singapore to expand their footprints overseas.

Being a trusted logistics partner to SMEs for over 40 years, we have an acute understanding of their needs and have tailored our solutions to help them internationalise. Helping SMEs figure out complex cross-border shipping and trading regulations as well as moving their packages efficiently, effectively and safely via our established networks are some of the ways we are assisting SMEs to thrive in foreign markets. We have also introduced new payment methods targeted at helping SMEs do business with us.

As fast-growing countries such as Myanmar, Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia open up their economies in the wake of the AEC, they will be looking to leverage Singapore's technological maturity to scale up their high-value industries - including biomedical, aerospace and maritime. With intimate knowledge of these verticals and effective logistics support, we will enable our SMEs to become successful first movers and capture the most strategic opportunities in these sectors.

Wahab Yusoff

Vice-President, South Asia

McAfee (part of Intel Security)

I AM very excited about the opportunities that come with an Asean Economic Community - both for businesses as well as for the positive economic impact on the lives of the people in the region.

If you look at the AEC blueprint, it is clear that a secure and connected information infrastructure is important for sustaining the region's economic growth and competitiveness.

For our industry, I expect the AEC to have a positive impact on cyber security, as member countries will be encouraged to share a cache of cyber security information as well as align their cyber education efforts.

Today we are witnessing constantly evolving, complex cyber attacks and threats to our information technology that don't stop at geographic boarders and are multinational by nature.

Therefore, it is crucial to unite in the fight against cyber criminals as traditional island solutions like firewalls or standalone defences are no longer adequate.

With the McAfee Security Connected approach we are already implementing the next generation of security solutions that use cloud intelligence to safeguard businesses from advanced attacks. This tremendously speeds up the readiness and robustness of our clients' cyber defence.

We are already working closely with governments and the private sector across Asean as one of our fastest growing markets, and look forward to cooperating with our partners, especially in the public sector, to safeguard the information infrastructure required for the next phase of growth through the launch of the AEC.

Adam Judd

Vice-President for APAC

Brocade

THE high-tech sector will stand to benefit immensely from the AEC, particularly in the areas of human capital transfer, infrastructure expansion and capacity building. The effective development of cross-border infrastructure will be crucial to achieving the AEC and integrating industries such as telecommunications, energy and transport. As such, spending on IT projects is expected to increase exponentially across the region.

At Brocade, we are already working with service providers and governments to help evolve their communication networks, through software networking technology that can be easily integrated with the current infrastructure, so that they can meet the growing demands of data- and bandwidth-intensive applications in an increasingly distributed environment.

Joshua Soh

Managing Director for Singapore and Brunei

Cisco

THE AEC 2015 is set to transform the way countries in the region connect, collaborate and thrive. The regional economic integration will result in economic transformation, social innovation and community enablement for these Asean countries.

It is a great opportunity to share our combined knowledge so that our friends in the region can benefit from our experiences in the development cycle, allowing them to leapfrog into a future-ready country. Our experiences with tried and tested solutions that work in Asia and our regional network of partners will revolutionise Asean by providing the means with which businesses, governments, schools and people connect the unconnected.

With education and the Internet as the two great equalisers in life, a strong, ICT-trained workforce is critical to the success of the AEC 2015. We are excited that over the last 16 years, the Cisco Networking Academy programme has trained more than 4.8 million students across 8,500 academies in Asean.

Over the next five years, we have committed to train more than 400,000 ICT professionals across the region. This foundation of skills and knowledge will take Asean to 2015 and beyond.

Chris Mead

Regional Director

Hays in Singapore & Malaysia

GROUPING the economies of the 10 member-states of Asean into one Asean Economic Community should make the region very attractive and competitive on the international stage, which would increase business opportunities - and in turn create jobs. It's an exciting prospect for all businesses in the region, including recruiters such as Hays.

But in order to take advantage of this opportunity all organisations, from multinationals to small and medium-sized enterprises, need the right staff. That's why we've achieved the world-leading ISO 9001:2008 certification in recognition of a management system conforming to world-leading standards.

In a competitive global market, this gives AEC employers the opportunity to work with a recruiter with the world's best processes and practices - a rarity in South-east Asia.

After all, with the right planning and the right people with the right skills in the right position, achieving world-class success is absolutely possible.

Toh Han Li

Chief Executive

Competition Commission of Singapore

WITH the advent of the Asean Economic Community in 2015, we expect to see even more Singapore companies expanding their operations into the region to tap the additional growth opportunities afforded by the AEC. It is therefore important for companies to have the necessary assurances and protection when accessing these overseas markets as new entrants.

To this end, one of the pillars of Asean economic integration is to put in place national competition laws to ensure a level playing field for businesses operating in the region. The current Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership under negotiation is a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) of Asean member states and their FTA partners. When concluded, it will complement the AEC and covers non-tariff barriers such as impediments to market competition. This will further encourage trade and investment flows into and within the Asean region and create benefits for both consumers and businesses.

Christophe Duchatellier

CEO

Adecco Asia

WITHIN the human capital space, the impact of the Asean Economic Community would result in a highly dynamic and interesting marketplace. Already businesses and organisations are having borderless interactions; the formation of the AEC will bring a positive impact to the way we do business here in Asia.

From a talent perspective, such an initiative will open doors, thus creating a vibrant economy where talent is mobile, agile and available. This is particularly important in ensuring that we do not suffer from a brain drain and also in providing jobs and opportunities to the current and future workforce. This will also impact the way we recruit and retain our employees and how we drive our business.

Sam Yap

Group Executive Chairman and Co-Founder

Htwo Investment Holdings Pte Ltd

THE AEC in 2015 will probably have a bigger impact on some business sectors compared to others. In the education, enrichment and family care services sector, there will also be opportunities for business development for the local providers to tap the potential demand of educational and enrichment services for the AEC marketplace.

Potential is greatest in the developing countries like Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos. There are already established links within Asean on early childhood education and services for families. This is mainly focused on the provision of educational and care services to young children and on empowering women and families on socio-economic issues.

Business entrepreneurs in the education sector could leverage further on the existing links and networks with partners within AEC to take their business in the region to a higher level through innovative and creative programmes that these developing countries can adapt for their local markets.

Htwo Holdings sees this as a potential target for our business growth outside China. We will study how we can be part of this new economic cooperation and make Asean a competitive economic region.

Alan Leong

Vice-President for Asia Pacific

Silver Peak

THE easing of regulation on goods, labour, services and capital is likely to attract more investment into South-east Asia as businesses continue to tap into the region for growth opportunities.

As companies expand across markets, there's a burgeoning need for better network coordination between local offices and their regional headquarters. In order for the Asean Economic Community to function as the powerhouse of South-east Asia, businesses must contend with the adverse effects of distance, network quality and capacity, all of which can slow down the transfer and accessibility of data, which can ultimately impact business productivity.

As the 10-member states join forces, organisations need to ensure that replication of data over greater distances, between cities and across countries are in place, especially in natural disaster-prone areas. In addition, it is crucial that all information shared across networks are protected and kept secure, both for regulatory and compliance reasons, and to maintain customer trust.

Dora Hoan

Co-Chairman/Group CEO

Best World International Ltd

I THINK the impact will be positive. While my company has successfully expanded into Asean countries, we have faced problems such as high import tax and product registration issues. We need to spend time and money for the same product to go through product registration in every country every year.

With the Asean Economic Community, we can look forward to the elimination of such hassles. Taxes will be removed and the procedures standardised. As we already have subsidiaries and markets in various Asean countries, my company is ready to take immediate advantage of the opportunities from the AEC. Now, we are just waiting.

Ronald Lee

Managing Director

PrimeStaff Management Services Pte Ltd

THE vision of the Asean Economic Community is commendable. Its ultimate effectiveness, however, boils down to its execution and how everything will be coordinated between all 10 member-states. Human resources development and capacity building is one of the areas that has been specifically singled out in the AEC blueprint so this should bode well for our industry. The removal of restrictions on trade of services between member-states will facilitate the free flow of services and I certainly welcome any such measures that will help smoothen the path for PrimeStaff's expansion into the region.

Our recruitment division already helps clients fulfil job placements across the Asia Pacific from our base in Singapore and we have been in expansion mode this year, regardless of the AEC. If the AEC can facilitate the opening of new markets for us and accelerate cross-market opportunities, that would be wonderful.

David Low

CEO

Futuristic Store Fixtures Pte Ltd

AS a store fixtures specialist supporting international retail brands in their growth initiatives, the establishment of the AEC is most welcomed. We have manufacturing facilities in Malaysia and a common market will allow output in Malaysia to be delivered at zero tariff within Asean countries, making production in Malaysia as competitive as, if not more so than, in China. Operating costs have always been one of the many crucial considerations for our clients when it comes to creating greater retail presence.

The AEC will potentially put Asean on a level playing field with the current two economic giants, China and India. The pull factors will increase, including rising GDP which will serve to attract more international retailers to expand aggressively in this region.

With the presence of a large pool of relatively untapped young talent in Asean, coupled with China re-calibrating herself towards consumerism and labour cost adjustments, we could be seeing more foreign direct investments in Asean compared to past periods. We are very much looking forward to the good news in 2015 as we continue to serve a plethora of diverse retail brands.

David Leong

Managing Director

PeopleWorldwide Consulting Pte Ltd

AN Asean Economic Community as an economic bloc tied by commonalities of interests and geography opens doors for its members. The free flow of trade, goods, services and people across borders will strengthen the community as a whole. This is particularly so for Singapore as among the Asean nations we are the smallest and poorest with natural and human resources. Singapore thrives by sheer tenacity, imagination and innovativeness in creating opportunities for itself. We became a centre for financial activities and transhipment.

PeopleWorldwide aims to build a database of human talent in the Asean community by identifying and connecting these human assets to opportunities through Web and mobile technologies. We hope to play a critical role as a gateway to talent and labour migration. We aim to build a big databank of such talent and connect them to business opportunities, and help to build a better future for them.

By gearing up our IT infrastructure, PeopleWorldwide hopes to become the transhipment port for talent management and an effective gateway to talent and labour within the Asean community.

site_title: Institutional interest in Basel III bonds gains strength
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Institutional interest in Basel III bonds gains strength

Just over 40% of UOB's $500m Basel III-compliant bonds taken up by insurers

Published Sun, May 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] UOB's early and steady march in the issuance of Basel III-compliant bonds offers a case study on shifting appetite for such bonds.

This has been highlighted in its latest $500 million Singapore-dollar Basel III-compliant bond, which was priced last week, sources say.

Just over 40 per cent of the callable bond issue - the fourth Basel III instrument issued by UOB to date - were taken up by insurance companies, making them the single-largest investor in the latest instrument issued by the bank.

This was followed by high net worth individuals, who took up 34 per cent of the total issue.

The bonds were in strong demand, with the order book exceeding $1.25 billion, a source said. Investors will earn an interest fixed at the rate of 3.5 per cent on the principal for these bonds. They are due 2026 but can be called for redemption in 2020.

This compares with the 11 per cent of insurance companies that took up UOB's first Basel III-compliant bonds. The issue, which raised $850 million for the bank, had nearly 75 per cent of the investment coming from private banking investors instead.

To be sure, some terms of the first bond issue are different - those are perpetual securities, which means they have no expiry date. Holders of that bond earn an interest of 4.9 per cent.

Still, the change reflects that institutional investors are now more comfortable and aware of the non-viability loss absorption provisions contained in Basel III instruments, a banker said.

UOB has been the most active among the three homegrown banks in issuing Basel III-compliant bonds. For a new instrument to qualify as bank capital under the Basel III framework, it must be able to absorb losses - either through write-downs or conversion into common equity - in the event the issuing bank hits a "point of non-viability".

"We have seen this shift as part of a global trend, in particular with the recent Basel III capital issues by Asian banks, where institutional participation has been strong," the banker said.

UOB also priced the latest bond instrument - to qualify as Tier-2 capital - at 25 basis points tighter than the initial guidance of 3.75 per cent, the source said.

This comes on the back of Singapore banks' strong credit standing. UOB has also shown a "disciplined approach to growth", the banker said.

As a comparison, UOB's Basel II Tier-2 bonds, which are callable in 2017, are trading around 2.8 per cent. If adjusted for a three-year tenure extension to compare with the latest instrument callable in 2020, those "old-style" bonds would offer additional yield of up to 80 basis points.

This means the latest bonds were priced at little or no premium to comparative bonds trading now, and reflect competitive pricing, said Leong Hong Yew, UOB's head of capital management.

site_title: Dassault Systèmes aims to tap more of Asean potential
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Dassault Systèmes aims to tap more of Asean potential

French software giant wants to spread the '3D experience' as much as possible. VICTORIA HO reports

Published

Sun, May 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AS AN aerospace engineer in the 1970s, Philippe Forestier often had to work with wooden prototypes of planes on his drafting board. The simulation process was a long-drawn-out event, barely resembling what engineers can do today in a split second, thanks to 3D technology, says the executive VP of global affairs and communities with French 3D software giant Dassault Systèmes. As one of the founding members of Dassault Systèmes, Mr Forestier has had the privilege of a front-row seat over the past three decades of 3D software's evolution.

Dassault Systèmes was a subsidiary of the Dassault Group spun out in 1981 to develop the company's computer-aided design (CAD) software called CATIA. Short for computer-aided three-dimensional interactive application, CATIA started as an in-house project in 1977 to design fighter jets. Later, it won big-name clients like Boeing, which adopted CATIA in the 1980s as its main CAD tool.

From the initial team of 10, today Dassault Systèmes is 12,000-people strong, said Mr Forestier. The company had 2.1 billion euros (S$3.6 billion) in earnings in 2013, making it the largest French software publisher in terms of revenue. Its cash allows it to acquire, on average, one company per month. Its latest acquisitions point to new verticals that the company is eyeing, away from the aviation and manufacturing industry where it has already established a foothold, Mr Forestier revealed.

The life sciences, banking and retail verticals are particularly hot right now, and companies are incorporating 3D technology within their processes to gain an edge on the competition, he said. Last December, Dassault Systèmes acquired Munich-based Realtime Technology AG (RTT), which produces marketing and branding-oriented 3D software for companies like Audi, Electrolux, General Motors and Harley-Davidson. Earlier this year, it acquired Accelerys, which made software for the chemical and life sciences industry. And in 2012, it bought Silicon Valley dotcom Netvibes, which made social media and Web-based applications.

All of these investments are aimed at extending the ability of 3D software to simulate as much of a business as possible - a process Dassault has dubbed the "3D experience". This involves simulating the building and management of materials of a product, all the way to the way the product is displayed in stores and how users will interact with the retail outlet, explained Mr Forestier.

"A good product by an engineer is not necessarily a good product in the consumer experience," he said.

A car company five years ago would deploy Dassault's technology only for the development and engineering of new vehicles; today, many of the main players are simulating how a car would feel to a user.

RTT, for example, produced software that would realistically simulate videos of cars and car parts. Many car advertisements are executed virtually, on software like RTT's, allowing them more dynamic footage otherwise not possible with real-life video, said Mr Forestier. "They hardly use real cars for car advertisements now."

For retail, P&G is a Dassault customer that uses its software to design products from bottles to razors, to baby diapers. "They design the bottle of the shampoo but they also place it on the shelf in a (virtual) context of a shop. The user interaction is tracked; the position of the item on the rack is not by chance," Mr Forestier said.

"When I started in the industry, the idea was to remove the need for the drafting table. Now (companies) do virtually everything from end-to-end, not just simulate the prototype."

The ability to get into the "experience" service opens the door for Dassault Systèmes to sectors like banking and F&B, where the customer experience is often unique to the location, and companies operating within the industry are smaller than large MNCs. This will help Dassault penetrate South-east Asia, which remains largely untapped for the company, Mr Forestier said.

France alone makes up 10 per cent of the 3D company's business, while the Asean region collectively makes up just 2 per cent, he said. About a third of its business is done in the US, and another third in Europe as a whole.

"We can do much more here," Mr Forestier admitted.

The company has offices in Singapore and Indonesia in Asean. Elsewhere in Asia, it has multiple offices in China, India, South Korea and Japan.

"We are not yet in Myanmar, or Laos or Cambodia, but those countries are interesting to us because of the GDP growth there," he said.

It plans to focus on the life sciences and energy sectors in the region, where most customers are trying to use 3D simulation to reduce waste. Mining companies are using data analytics to better narrow down where they can drill for resources, to reduce cost and the amount of trash generated, for example.

"We sell our systems to C-level people because they understand that they need to transform the business. We don't sell IT to IT people because they don't like adoption changes in the way they work," Mr Forestier noted.

For now, customers in the region are mostly interested in product lifecycle management software. Eventually, as these companies expand, Dassault hopes to push its "customer experience" software to them, he said.

site_title: Mexico's Ara suspends malls' collective sale
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Mexico's Ara suspends malls' collective sale

Published

Mon, May 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SAO PAULO] Consorcio Ara SAB has suspended an auction to sell a group of about US$387 million of shopping malls and is now considering selling the centres individually.

The company was working with Morgan Stanley on the sale of the malls, which the Mexico City-based builder co-owns with New York-based private-equity firm O'Connor Capital Partners Inc, said investor relations official Alicia Enriquez. While the contract with Morgan Stanley is still valid, Ms Enriquez said the formal sale process stalled when the top bidder failed to obtain sufficient financing. "What we're looking for is the best offer, and we're not in a rush to sell," Ms Enriquez said.

Keeping the properties means Ara will forego a cash infusion at a time when the home-building industry is reeling from a shift in government housing policy.

Competitors Desarrolladora Homex SAB and Corp Geo SAB filed earlier this year for bankruptcy, known as concurso mercantil in Mexico, and Urbi Desarrollos Urbanos SAB is working with Rothschild to consider options including restructuring debt.

Ms Enriquez said Ara is studying the possibility of selling the malls individually, because some bidders in the original auction had expressed interest only in specific assets.

The malls were valued at around five billion pesos (S$484 million), two people with knowledge of the properties said last year. CEO German Ahumada Russek had projected Ara would net at least 1.3 billion pesos from its portion of the shopping centres after paying associated debt.

The collapse of its competitors means Ara is the sector's biggest publicly traded company, with a market value of 7.6 billion pesos.

Mr Ahumada Russek also said on a conference call last month that Ara is bound by the conditions of a syndicated loan to withhold dividends during the repayment period, unless the malls are sold or a waiver is obtained.

Homebuilder's cash balances plummeted last year and some companies wrote down land reserves after the government reallocated subsidies and financing for low-income homes to encourage city living instead of rural developments. The move was a reaction to urban sprawl and the subsequent exodus that had turned some subsidised developments into ghost towns, even as builders stockpiled more inexpensive farm land.- Bloomberg

SUBSCRIBERS

Goodpack hits highs amid reports of KKR talks

Published

Mon, May 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Goodpack's shares continued marching to record highs yesterday, amid news reports that it is in advanced talks with US private equity firm KKR & Co.

Its shares ended two cents higher at S$2.47 yesterday, far above the record of S$2.15 last reached in July 2007. Its shares have risen for four straight days, with increased trading volumes in the last two.

Reuters and Wall Street Journal (WSJ), quoting unnamed sources, yesterday reported that KKR is nearing a deal to buy the Singapore packaging logistics company for at least US$1 billion.

In an update yesterday on its talks with various parties on a possible transaction, Goodpack said that "matters have progressed" since April 17 and that it was now continuing talks with one of the parties.

While Goodpack had reportedly held meetings with two other private equity players Blackstone Group and Carlyle Group early last month, The Business Times understands that they had dropped out of the running.

But the run-up in the share price could imperil the KKR deal as well, given that minority shareholders could ask for a larger premium over an already increased share price.

CapitaLand, which has launched a takeover for CapitaMalls Asia, has had to sweeten the deal by raising the offer price after minority shareholders and market watchers complained that it was too low; in another deal, Ong Beng Seng and Wheelock Properties also raised their offer price for shares in Hotel Properties Ltd after they bought shares in married trades at a higher price.

There is no certainty yet that a deal may happen, according to WSJ.

Goodpack's shares have risen 22 per cent from S$2.03 since the firm first said on March 19 that it has been approached by unnamed parties which could lead to a general offer being made. The company has appointed Rippledot Capital Advisers as its financial adviser, and its founder David Lam - who owns 32 per cent of the firm - is said to be open towards a takeover offer.

KKR set up its South- east Asia office in Singapore in October 2012, and the potential acquisition would mark its first deal here since then.

Goodpack has, over the years, attracted various suitors.

In 2008, it hired Macquarie to look at strategic alternatives - from a sale to a strategic buyer to bringing in new investors. At that time, Australian packing companies Loscam and Brambles were reported to be interested in bidding for the firm.

Brambles, which leases wooden pallets, reusable plastic containers and intermediate bulk containers (IBCs) to the fast-moving consumer goods industry, said on March 20 that while it has engaged in preliminary discussions with Goodpack on several previous occasions, including in the recent past, these did not progress.

Analysts attribute Goodpack's appeal to its strong position in a market niche and its global network which makes for a wide economic moat.

Goodpack rents reusable IBCs to tyre manufacturers, chemical and juice producers such as Michelin, Bridgestone, BASF, Campbell and Heinz, for use in transporting their products, replacing the traditional wooden boxes and metal drums used in these industries.

The firm last Monday posted a 20.2 per cent increase in third-quarter net profit to US$13.1 million. Revenue rose 14.2 per cent to US$51.2 million.

content:

OSX Brasil offers to pay debt over 25 years

Published

Sun, May 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[RIO DE JANEIRO] OSX Brasil SA, the bankrupt shipbuilder controlled by former billionaire Eike Batista, has presented a plan to a court to pay US$2.6 billion in debt over 25 years.

Under the plan, OSX will start repaying the bulk of its debts after three years, the company said. It also allows the company to seek new capital, including the sale of stakes to new investors. The company said on Friday it hoped to generate new revenue by finding partners interested in using areas it owns at the giant Port of Acu complex north of Rio de Janeiro.

Rio de Janeiro-based OSX filed for bankruptcy protection in November as part of the unravelling of the once high-flying EBX Group of oil, electricity, port, shipbuilding and mining companies that Mr Batista assembled during an economic boom in Brazil that fizzled in 2011. The group has seen its value nearly evaporate in the last two years.

Despite the plan's three-year grace period for repayment, OSX Brasil will set aside 25,000 reals (S$11,290) to be divided among all creditors within a year of the plan's approval. This will repay obligations to about half the individuals and companies owed money by OSX.

Another 80,000 reals will be paid within a year to creditors of OSX Brasil subsidiary OSX Construcao Naval. - Reuters

site_title: Kanesaka branches out
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Kanesaka branches out

Michelin-starred sushi chef Shinji Kanesaka re-opens second outlet in larger premises at St Regis Singapore. JAIME EE checks it out

Published

Sun, May 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

NEW RESTAURANT

Shinji By Kanesaka

The St Regis Singapore

Lobby Floor

29 Tanglin Road

Tel: 6884-8239

Open for lunch and dinner Mon to Sat: 12pm to 3pm; 6pm to 10.30pm

SO who wasn't briefly annoyed with Barack Obama for not even finishing his food at Sushi Jiro in Tokyo - the subject of food porn documentary Jiro Dreams of Sushi? Especially when lesser mortals try in vain to get a coveted seat at this supposedly seminal sushi-ya?

You wonder whether it's hype or skill that makes one chef's sushi taste better than another's. The 80-something sushi master Jiro has a son who has his own successful two-Michelin star joint in Tokyo, but it's still the old man's shop that people fight to get into. But doesn't it logically follow that if someone is taught by a master and has the same fish supplier, the sushi at both shops should be equally good?

Obviously, people don't agree, and therein lies the conundrum for master sushi chefs banking on this theory to expand their business.

Take Shinji Kanesaka, the two-starred sushi chef who's spawned a string of restaurants in Tokyo and now Singapore. Is it possible to duplicate and export the same experience of eating sushi that he developed and which earned him his precious stars in the first place?

Theoretically, you can reproduce the hardware - the one-piece hinoki counters, standardised recipes, make all your chefs shave their heads and use the same quality fish. You can even give your chefs the exact same training.

But the reality remains. It doesn't matter whose name is on the door. The taste of the sushi you eat is a product of the guy who made it, not the one who taught him.

So, you may be eating in Kanesaka's sushi restaurant in Singapore, but forget about eating the man's sushi per se. Once you get over that, you can settle down and gauge the food for what it is - high-end, high-priced, still-enjoyable experience at the hands of his personally picked chefs sent here to fly the flag.

People were originally attracted to the first Shinji by Kanesaka in Raffles Hotel because of the Michelin connection, but it was still up to head chef Oshino Koichiro to build his own following. Now, at Kanesaka's newest offspring at the St Regis Singapore, head chef Kikuchi Shunsuke has been tasked to do the same.

The St Regis premises offers larger, more luxurious digs compared to its previous location within Chinese restaurant Tong Le at OUE Tower. And on the plus side, it's slightly easier (for now) to get a seat at St Regis than in the Raffles.

If you're looking for dependable sushi in an authentic setting, and psychologically prepared to pay at least $125 for lunch (12 pieces) and up to $450 for omakase at dinner, there's really little difference between the two.

Ingredients-wise, the quality is generally good with the occasional high, but there is no way to compete with the six-hour flight advantage that eating in Tokyo has. Nor can you compare the price, especially when you can get a top-of-the-line omakase by a three Michelin starred sushi chef for a little over $300. If you can get a booking in the first place.

Nonetheless, you can still get a decent Tokyo-style experience with crowd-pleasers such as silky-textured tofu paired with sweet uni, tender simmered abalone, seasonal firefly squid lightly marinated and if lucky, a choice morsel of engawa - the prized fin from hirame or flounder. Little tea lights fashioned from daikon slices add a lovely touch to the intricately arranged platter of appetisers (tsumami). Tender, melting-soft grilled nodokuro (black throat perch), crab meat blanketed with sheets of beancurd skin or yuba and uni paired with sweet baby shrimp are some highlights of its $450 set.

While raw and cooked dishes are consistent, it's a different story when it comes to sushi. The $125 Tsuki course features 12 pieces of the usual suspects: hirame, a lovely golden eye snapper, horse mackerel, otoro and chutoro, uni, shrimp and anago. The rice is warm and chewy, but our sushi chef has an inconsistent hand with the wasabi, clearing our sinuses more often than necessary. And if you don't ask, he won't automatically tell you what you're eating when he hands you each piece.

In comparison, when the restaurant opened, Kanesaka-san himself made an appearance and we were able to compare two pieces made by him with that of his other chefs. The difference was clear - his was on a totally different level.

But why? The same rice and fish were used but in his hands, they came together in the right consistency, texture, temperature and flavour.

Call it the heart, or even the spirit of the chef that goes into each piece of sushi that differentiates it from others, but maybe that's what Jiro's dreams of sushi are all about. You can't franchise a chef's personal touch. But take heart. You're not eating Kanesaka's sushi, but it's not that hard to get used to it.

Rating:

7

SUBSCRIBERS

Brazil's new airport terminal glistens amid stumbles

Rare success story in rush to get infrastructure ready for June World Cup

Published

Sun, May 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SAO PAULO] Walking through Sao Paulo's new airport terminal, you'd never suspect the trouble coursing through the city ahead of the World Cup that Brazil will begin hosting next month.

Sunlight illuminates the gleaming, soaring wing of Guarulhos International Airport that opened last week, ready to receive the estimated 600,000 visitors who will fly in for the monthlong international soccer tournament.

Terminal 3, at 192,000 square metres, is slightly larger than Terminals 1, 2 and 4 combined and has the capacity to receive as many as 12 million passengers a year. The cathedral-height interior dwarfs the claustrophobic T1 and T2, built with concrete and one strip of skylight in 1985.

The glass structure is a bright spot of success amid other transportation projects and stadiums that remain unfinished. Construction has been delayed by cost overruns and even the death of workers. Brazil is also mired in protests and deadly clashes from Sao Paulo to Rio de Janeiro as citizens show their opposition to what many consider misguided public spending on new arenas and infrastructure rather than education and social services.

"This seems to be the only success story," said Ricardo Gazetta, a sales manager at loyalty points company Multiplus SA in Sao Paulo. He was checking in for a flight to Porto, Portugal, on TAP SGPS on May 13. "It looks like a serious building - it's huge, beautiful."

Brazil has failed to deliver on 45 per cent of the infrastructure projects it promised to build when it won the right to host the championship in 2007, according to a study done by Portal da Copa 2014, a World Cup news website run by the national architecture and engineering union.

The terminal - built with sustainable engineering including water recycling and windows with heat filters - was finished on time and within the 2.9 billion real (S$1.63 billion) allotted budget, said Gustavo Figueiredo, chief operations officer of Terminal 3, in a telephone interview. About 8,000 people were employed and workers dug and drilled 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

Grupo Invepar, owned by the OAS SA construction company and government-associated pension funds, and Airports Co South Africa won the right to build the terminal and operate the airport when it was auctioned off in 2012 in the form of a 20-year contract.

"Operationally, it's been a success from day one," Mr Figueiredo said, citing the installation of scanners to get people through the gates, eliminating the need for employees. - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

More PDPA guidelines and initiatives in store

Three more sectors - healthcare, education and social services - get directions in run-up to July 2, when new law will fully kick in

Published

Fri, May 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE dust continues to settle around the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA), with three more sectors - healthcare, education and social services - getting guidelines on the new law.

A public consultation was launched yesterday for these three sets of sector-specific guidelines in the run-up to July 2, when the PDPA fully kicks in.

"These are some of the sectors which typically have to handle personal data in high volumes," a Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) spokesman said yesterday.

These guidelines follow another set issued earlier this year for the real estate agency and telecommunications sectors - the final versions of which were also released yesterday.

More public consultations for other sectors might follow, with the PDPC already in talks with representatives from banking and life insurance.

In the healthcare guidelines released yesterday, various scenarios outlining the collection of personal data from patients seeking medical care were dealt with. A clinic that wants to use a patient's personal data to market health products to him that are unrelated to his condition, for example, needs to tell the patient what the data will be used for and get his consent.

The guidelines for the education sector also clarify several issues, including the need to obtain a student's consent before disclosing his personal details to various parties. Schools which want to publish the names and photographs of top students and alumni in their marketing material should get these individuals' consent as well.

The social service guidelines, meanwhile, deal with how the personal data of a person who is receiving services from volunteer welfare organisations should be handled, among various things.

The PDPA exists alongside sector-specific laws - like the Private Hospitals and Medical Clinics Act for healthcare, for instance. Where the PDPA conflicts with other written laws, the latter will supersede the former. Under the Infectious Diseases Act, for example, if a medical practitioner suspects that someone he is treating has an infectious disease, he is required to notify the director of medical services. In this case, the medical professional does not have to get the individual's consent to divulge this information.

The rules governing photography were also up for consultation from yesterday. Scenarios covered in the guidelines include whether an individual who voluntarily poses for a photograph is deemed to have given his consent for the photo-taking.

Consultation on these guidelines will close on June 6 at noon.

Yesterday, the PDPC also clarified that, generally, the age of 13 is the minimum threshold for minors who can consent to the collection and handling of their data, unless the law specifies otherwise. As a rule of thumb, someone who is at least 13 years old would have "sufficient understanding to be able to consent on his own behalf", the PDPC reckoned.

The commission also shed more light on firms' obligation to provide individuals with access to their personal data that is kept on hand and the option to correct that data.

An organisation has to respond within 30 days when an individual makes such an access or correction request. If it is unable to do so, it must tell the person in writing the earliest possible time that it can respond.

While the PDPC's stance is that a firm may charge a "reasonable" fee to recover the incremental costs of carrying out this obligation, it has not prescribed a benchmark fee at this point.

As July 2 looms, Minister for Communications and Information Yaacob Ibrahim announced a raft of measures to help firms adjust to the new rules yesterday.

Later this month, two-day courses developed by the PDPC and the Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA) will be offered for employees involved in data protection matters. WDA funding ranging from 70-90 per cent of the course fee is available.

In August, a free e-learning programme that helps organisations to learn about their PDPA obligations will also be offered on the PDPC website. "This gives organisations an additional resource to conduct self-directed learning to ensure compliance with the PDPA," Dr Yaacob said.

Even after all that, if man and organisation still come to fisticuffs over personal data when the Act comes into full effect, both the Consumers' Association of Singapore and the Singapore Mediation Centre will be ready to provide mediation services for disputes.

site_title: Gamification a growing trend: DBS, SingTel
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Gamification a growing trend: DBS, SingTel

Published

Sun, May 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

GAMIFICATION, or the use of gaming elements in a non-gaming environment to increase engagement with target consumers, is an emerging trend that will be at the forefront of every business, said DBS Bank's Christopher Ng and SingTel's Cheong Hai Thoo.

Mr Ng, DBS' vice-president of group strategic marketing and communications, said that gamification, if done correctly, would translate into better customer engagement, acquisition and awareness for companies.

"People are always on their phones and play games to fill up their time whenever they commute, so there's a lot of opportunities for us to take note of that dead time and leverage on that," he said.

According to SingTel, in 2013, 79 per cent of Singaporeans, or 4.2 million people, were gaming on their mobile devices. Of that, 26 per cent spend a monthly average of $5.23 on their mobile gaming habits.

"We see the entire industry shifting from a small group of consumers to a very enlarged group of gamers," said Mr Cheong, head of FunLife, the digital content group for SingTel.

DBS has created its own suite of games to achieve various outcomes. One of its games,WhyMoolah, is designed to creatively teach and reward players for good money management practices through simulation and stories. Another game, called Dragon Tap, is a virtual dragonboat rowing game that generates awareness for the DBS Marina Regatta 2014, a water sports festival.

"We look at the user being at the centre of our attention because we're looking more at acquisition these days and converting people other than just working with our customers," said Mr Ng.

WhyMoolah has had over 25,000 downloads since its debut in November. This has helped DBS achieve its internal customer acquisition as well as engagement targets. It also allowed the bank to analyse real-time feedback generated from the players' behaviours to improve its games.

However, when it comes to deciding how to measure the return on investment (ROI) of such gaming applications, Mr Ng said that it depends on what business objectives a company wishes to achieve. For example, Dragon Tap's purpose is merely to drive awareness of DBS' water sports festival, so there is no need for DBS to measure monetary outcomes.

It may be hard to quantify ROI but Mr Cheong advised companies to experiment with gamification as the gaming industry is, by nature, a hit-or-miss business.

"For every Candy Crush, there're another 10,000 games that got crushed . . . but the moment you get it, that kind of engagement and level of stickiness is quite amazing," he said.

He also stressed the need to create games that are easy to play yet good enough to retain gamers, saying: "I think the whole make-or-break for gamification lies in two very critical components: One, it (the game) must be simple enough to attract users. Two, it must be sophisticated enough to retain the user once they get on board. At the end of the day, it's a balance between these two."

Nasa to test drone in commercial airspace

Researchers to study sense-and-avoid technology that warns of planes

Published Sun, May 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[ORLANDO] The Predator drone, known for its stealthy strikes on terrorists, will begin flight tests early next year to prove that large unmanned aircraft are safe while operating amid commercial planes.

Researchers will be studying so-called sense-and-avoid technology, designed to alert the drone's remote pilot to nearby aircraft, according to Chuck Johnson, senior adviser for unmanned and autonomous systems at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (Nasa).

Nasa's goal: Harvest data that will help design systems so that big drones can fly above 18,000 feet, in airspace used by airliners, cargo planes and business jets. Pilotless aircraft could be used to haul freight or hover high in the sky to beam Internet signals across remote terrain, Mr Johnson said.

Shanmugam welcomes firmer action by Vietnam

Published

Sun, May 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Singapore Foreign Minister K Shanmugam welcomed Vietnam's assurance of firm action against protests at two Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Parks (VSIPs), and highlighted to his Vietnamese counterpart the impact of unrest on business confidence.

Mr Shanmugam "expressed Singapore's deep concern over the riots that had taken place, and highlighted that the VSIPs were endorsed by the governments of Vietnam and Singapore", the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) said in a statement.

Vietnamese Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs Pham Binh Minh had called Mr Shanmugam on May 16 to discuss the protests in Binh Duong province. Mr Minh had assured Mr Shanmugam that Vietnam will take all necessary steps to ensure that the parks were properly protected, and that Vietnamese authorities will take firm action to deal with the situation.

Mr Shanmugam said the burning of a Singapore flag on May 13 by protesters was unacceptable.

Protests erupted in Vietnam a week ago as anger boiled over regarding China's recent deployment of an oil rig in disputed waters.

The unrest hit two Sembcorp Industries-run industrial parks, among others, with factories and buildings looted and burned.

Riot police have been stationed at the industrial park.

Do Nhat Hoang, director of Vietnam's Foreign Investment Agency, has said that the Vietnamese government will compensate affected companies.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Posh and down-to-earth

Private jets and a personal entourage may be prerequisites for Victoria Beckham, but the fashion designer insists on taking a reality check when it comes to work and family. By May Yip

Published

Fri, May 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ONE could hardly reconcile the vision of Victoria Beckham, as she girlishly twirls a strand of her impeccably coiffed tresses while speaking in a clipped accent, with the bleached blonde, bulbous-breasted Posh Spice. The cleavage is still enviable, and tan a shade of deep mahogany, but the singer-turned-WAG-turned-fashion-mogul is the epitome of, well, actual poshness.

The 40-year-old stunner has been hushing critics ever since she unveiled her eponymous label six years ago through her refined and, in her words, "deceptively simple" designs. Earlier this month, she walked the red carpet of the Met Gala in a tiered column dress - a perfectly streamlined number she showed during a presentation at the Marina Bay Sands' ArtScience Museum last Saturday. Rather than resorting to over-the-top embellishments and second-skin silhouettes, the jet-setting mother of four obsesses instead on exquisitely finished pieces that fit into any smart wardrobe.

"To get such a stunning silhouette requires paying a lot of attention to the little details to enable a woman to put a dress on and feel so special," says Beckham, who was in town to launch her accessories line with designer accessories retailer On Pedder. "They make you think about posture and how you carry yourself."

And the ballet-trained businesswoman, who sits ramrod-straight throughout a group interview, is all about the finer points that make up the big picture.

"For me it's very important I work on my show and have six to eight minutes to put my message across with regard to my venue, clothes, hair and makeup, and the buyers come in and make their selection," says Beckham, who will be opening her first standalone boutique on London's Dover Street in September.

"With a standalone store I am making the buy for what I think my customer wants. My customer will come into my store and step into my world. I am a very visual person and pay a lot of attention to the ceiling details, the floors, the visuals. It's the first time the customer can see the brand through my eyes."

While it is evident that Beckham is a seasoned pro at the PR game - she expertly lowers her chin and parts her lips ever so slightly for the camera, the former Spice Girl still comes across as personable and even down-to-earth, quizzing one reporter about whether she finds it easier dealing with her sons or daughters, and asking for beauty tips for tackling the humid weather.

"I think it's no different for me from any other working mum," says Beckham, whose youngest child Harper turns three this year.

"I get up quite early at six and that's when I do my workout and that's the time I have for me, and I am ready to take the children to school and I go to work. But I'm not going to sit here and say it's easy, any woman who works and is also a mum knows you feel guilty when you go to work, and I am not ashamed to say that."

Beckham almost has you thinking she's like any other multi-tasking career woman, rather than an uber-celeb whose home back in London is going to be a $63 million seven-bedroom mansion in Kensington. Nevertheless, the svelte glamazon is quick to demonstrate that she is a realistic businesswoman who designs for real, albeit flushed, women - and not just her celebrity BFFs. She admits that while her dresses are expensive, she has to be realistic about the types of fabric she uses and the "make cost" involved when creating a collection.

"I don't think you always have to be wearing luxury," says Beckham, when asked whether Singaporeans' laidback style is less than chic. "Casual is good, I lived in Los Angeles for six years and I loved every minute of it. It is more difficult to 'dress hot,' for sure."

While the avid art collector has been inspired by a Julian Schnabel for the colour palette of her pre-Fall collection, her inspirations could sometimes be somewhat more pedestrian: "One season, I saw my kid Romeo running into the kitchen in his baseball shirt and I was like, that's really cool. And I had a baseball thing, it was very subtle, that was running through the collection."

Family life, she insists, is her top priority even amid a busy schedule, which includes opening a New York office earlier this year.

"My proudest achievements are my children. They are a lot of work, but they're so very cute," gushes Beckham.

"I want my children to be happy. They are very sporty and they love fashion as well. But at the moment we need to focus on schoolwork and learning the times table. That seems the main challenge rather than if they will go into the fashion industry."

site_title: Herbalife thrives despite being under attack
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Herbalife thrives despite being under attack

Nutrition company saw record sales of US$4.8b in 2013; finds sweet spot in Asia-Pac, which contributed one-fourth of total sales

Anita Gabriel

Published

Fri, May 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

UNITED States-listed Herbalife's president, Des Walsh, may need to step up his marathon workouts, which he does dutifully once a year at southern California's seaside city, Huntington Beach.

Running is, after all, a great way to clear out work angst, something which those at the helm of Herbalife, a global nutrition company that sells healthy meals, appear to have plenty of these days.

For the past 16 months, the Cayman Islands-based marketer of vitamins and weight-loss shakes has been caught in a firestorm after hedge fund billionaire Bill Ackman waged a US$1 billion bet against the firm.

Labelling the diet shake maker a pyramid scheme, Mr Ackman, of Pershing Square Capital Management fund, forecast that Herbalife's stock price will plummet to zero. On the back of that, he has taken a huge short position on the NYSE-listed shares of the multi-level marketing firm.

That's not the only pressure the nutrition firm, with a market value of US$6 billion and run from Los Angeles, is under. Spurred by Mr Ackman's claims, the US Federal Trade Commission is looking into the firm's practices.

Operationally, though, the firm is on steady ground. Its top line grew 18 per cent in 2013 to record sales of US$4.8 billion, an accomplishment that Mr Walsh is understandably only too eager to emphasise.

"Think about it. How many companies can withstand months of an orchestrated, blistering, weekly campaign of negative information and yet still have a stronger business with more customers than ever before," says Mr Walsh in an interview with The Business Times.

Herbalife earned less in the first quarter this year due to foreign exchange losses but it still beat street estimates, encouraging analysts to raise their 2014 earnings projections.

This, says Mr Walsh, is proof of the legitimacy of the 34-year- old firm's business.

"We don't think he (Mr Ackman) has an interest in hearing or telling the truth. Remember, when you have a billion-dollar bet, it is not in your interest to have any information that you believe would be contrary to that," says Mr Walsh, who is in Singapore to launch a new product and hook up with distributors, his key mandate as the firm's president.

But the showdown with Mr Ackman, a shareholder class action against the firm and rife speculation that it is being probed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation have taken a toll on investor sentiment. The stock has lost 20 per cent of its value so far this year.

Still, at current levels of around US$60-$62, it is nearly double the price it was trading at in December 2012, when the activist investor Mr Ackman first launched his tirade against Herbalife.

That is in no small part due to the firm's counter-offensive huge share buyback plan of up to US$1.5 billion and its healthy financial showing. Comfort has also come from heavyweight investors George Soros, Carl Icahn and Dan Loeb, to name a few, who have thrown their money behind the firm and scooped up its shares.

Mr Walsh says that the company is not aware of any FBI probe and has not been contacted by the federal investigators.

The company has set up a "separate group" within the firm to react and respond to the allegations. "We will just have to see this whole thing play out and, meanwhile, we focus on our business," he says.

"It hasn't been terribly distracting as we recognise that the attacks have no legitimate basis. We knew that one of his (Mr Ackman's) objectives is to distract us and bring about an impact on the business. So we were determined not to let that happen."

A sweet market for the nutritional products maker is right here in the Asia-Pacific, the firm's biggest growth spot which contributed one-fourth of total sales last year.

A booming population, rising affluence and growing sense of well-being in this region stack up well for the firm's prospects.

Driving the growth is the concept of nutrition clubs, a fit club or social gathering where, for a daily fee, one gets to consume a shake or tea and engage in some activity.

"We are encouraging all members operating these clubs to introduce some form of activity - get a shake, have a chat and go out and walk for 10-15 minutes.

"These clubs drive our products deeper into the community," he says, adding that this is one way Herbalife has managed to tap a younger consumer demographic.

Singapore has 50 of these clubs out of the 17,000 scattered across the region and 55,000 around the world.

Containers, bulk carriers and tankers

Published Sun, May 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THREE main categories of merchant ships exist today.

Bulk carriers

convey unpacked commodities and are typically built to convey "wet" products such as oil or chemicals, or "dry" bulk such as grains or ore.

Bulk carriers are often identified by shorthand names ending with the suffix "-max". Examples include Panamaxes or Suezmaxes. These merely describe the size of the bulk carriers as some ports like the Suez Canal or the Panama Canal require ships to conform to certain dimensions in order to pass through these channels.
