site_title: Gender diversity in the boardroom
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Gender diversity in the boardroom

Is gender diversity the business of corporate boards? How do corporations ensure that their boards are broadly diverse?

Published

Sun, May 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Florence Ng

Managing Director, Founder

Straits Talent Pte Ltd

A DIVERSE team is a winning team. The best ideas and innovation often come out of left field. Diversity is the business of all corporate boards striving to succeed and stay ahead of their competitors. Gender diversity is part of this equation. That said, corporations need to value true diversity - which includes age, functional experience, industry knowhow, geographic and cultural differences, view-points, and so the list goes on.

The reason there is a dearth of women on corporate boards is clear - there are not enough of them in C-level positions to begin with. They often pass up on being ''CXO'' at work, and choose to become ''CDO'' (aka Chief Domestic Officer) at home. The pool of female talent available for board appointments is limited, to say the least. The fix for this is a lengthy and continuous exercise. Corporations, regulatory bodies and individuals alike all need to appreciate and support family-friendly measures so as to build a pipeline of capable womenfolk in key leadership positions. In time, they will form the gradually enlarged pool of talent for board appointments.

Anne Tong

Chief Executive Officer

HSR International Realtors Pte Ltd

THE role of corporate boards should primarily be to oversee the strategic direction of the company, facilitate effective decision-making and drive overall growth, among other functions. Ensuring gender diversity should not be a priority. What is imperative is to ensure good representation of diverse talents and views from individuals who are able to contribute.

While it is advisable for companies to be aware of the small percentage of female board directors and to perhaps consider this group should there be a position on the board to fill, gender diversity should not be mandated. Having women on the board solely for the sake of fulfilling a quota would be meaningless. However, in the case of companies which produce goods and services targeted at families, or customer service- and relationship-building industries, I believe exercising gender diversity would be an advantage as the board could benefit from female perspectives. Diversity can come in various other forms. Corporations can ensure diversity through a board made up of individuals with a range of experience, expertise, knowledge, talents and exposure to different markets.

Tim Moylan

President, Asia Pacific

Infor

SINGAPORE is an attractive location for companies to establish their regional headquarters, largely because of the country's diverse workforce which provides a wealth of perspectives and experiences to company decision-makers. As Singapore continues to position itself as an innovation and regional HQ hub, the value that a diverse management team brings to the workplace should be further recognised and promoted. Whether mandated or not, leaders of successful enterprises understand that employee and management team diversity - gender, cultural background, nationality, experiences, etc - supports a culture of greater innovation and helps companies adapt in today's globally competitive business environment.

For example, while the tech industry has been traditionally known as a boys' club, today we are embracing female leadership in the industry and moving conversations beyond traditional stereotypes. Female leaders in the tech world are driving companies forward as part of C-Suite leadership. Enterprises should continue to promote and support female leadership, as a diverse management team brings valuable ideas and different perspectives, and that's crucial to success.

Stefanie Yuen Thio

Joint Managing Director

TSMP Law Corporation

THE business of boards is not to ensure gender diversity. Their job is to manage the business of the company well. And of course every company is different so we should not expect to see uniform boards. But if you find a preponderance of company boards with only men (less than 8 per cent of directors are women), then surely you have to ask yourself: Are we really getting the best people on our boards? Statistically, it's not likely that less than 8 per cent of our top-calibre people are female. In which case, our business world needs to consider if it has tapped the available talent pool for the most capable individuals. And if study after study shows that diversity makes for a stronger board, then surely it's silly, and possibly irresponsible, to ignore them.

That said, I am firmly against quotas and other hard positive discrimination measures. Singapore is one of the most, if not the most, gender-equal places to work. Women can climb to the top of their careers on the basis of sheer merit, hard work and smarts. Having a quota for women on boards would be tokenism and would devalue what every woman executive has worked so hard to achieve. It would be putting a sexist glass ceiling where one never existed before.

Philip Yuen

Chief Executive Officer

Deloitte Singapore

THERE are generally two schools of thought to promote diversity - one involves affirmative actions in the form of regulations and the other leaves it to market forces or natural course of events. While we observe that regulators tend to favour a ''light touch'' approach, it would probably be more effective to let companies identify and recognise the value that such diversity could bring to their business, on a case-by-case basis.

A lot has already been done to raise the awareness of gender diversity on boards in recent years. Most companies have a nomination committee (NC) for its board of directors. The challenge lies in finding adequate and suitable candidates who will add value to the board. For this reason, the NC needs to spread its wings to consider and evaluate a more diverse group of candidates who will best contribute to the needs of the business and organisation.

Chris Comer

CEO

Castlewood Group

GENDER diversity is vital for every workplace to ensure a balanced playing field. However, the picture-perfect snapshot of a completely equal breakdown of staff, gender-wise, is unrealistic. Gender diversity is a major talking point globally and the issue is slowly making progress, but how the issue is tackled isn't the responsibility of corporate boards. The lack of females in the boardroom is an issue that needs to be addressed by the various advocacy groups and governing bodies supporting the empowerment of women.

Women need to be recognised for their skills and talent, and introducing a quota will most certainly undermine them. The Code of Corporate Governance should make a number of recommendations that include developing female-focused development courses that empower and identify key talents. By identifying female candidates who want to progress further in their career, corporations can create a pool of talent that can be nurtured for future senior roles and board positions.

We must remember that women are often a key demographic for marketers; their point of view is incomparable. While there shouldn't be a quota as such, it is in the corporations' best interests to assess the gender balance of their workplace and their board. Is it too male-dominated? If so, who is representing the female points of view? It makes perfect business sense to have a more equal workforce.

Men and women have different standpoints and market insights, which contribute to creating a holistic business outlook, leading to better-informed business decisions and performance.

''Give a man a fish, and you feed him for a day; show him how to catch fish, and you feed him for a lifetime.'' It is our responsibility as a company to equip our female staff with the skillset and confidence to get into the boardroom on their own merits.

Chris Mead

Regional Director

Hays in Singapore & Malaysia

AS recruiting experts, we believe that gender diversity is the business of corporate boards. The business case has been corroborated overseas but despite this, Singapore still ranks poorly when it comes to gender diversity.

Recruitment is about selecting the best person for the job and one of the biggest arguments against gender diversity is the merit argument. Of course the final recruitment decision should always be based on who possesses the most suitable skills and experience. But if there is not diversity in your application pool, how do you know you are selecting from the very best shortlist?

Therefore improving Singapore's gender diversity starts with ensuring diversity in an applicant pool. Hiring managers will then select the very best shortlist, from which they can pick the very best person. Provided all candidates are considered equally, this will naturally lead to a diverse workforce.

Other strategies include developing board-ready women through workplace flexibility, clear career paths and development opportunities.

Hugues Delcourt

Country Executive, ABN Amro Bank NV Singapore; and

CEO of ABN Amro Private Banking Asia & Middle East

GOOD decision-making on corporate boards requires hearing and considering different points of view, which can only come from members who have varied backgrounds, experiences and perspectives. Studies have also shown that diversity on corporate boards is typically associated with more effective corporate governance and improved financial value.

ABN Amro is committed to diversity across our global operations and at every level of the organisation. We believe board diversity is necessary to help steer the board to make better and relevant decisions for our business where clients are equally diverse and wide-ranging. Having women on boards is one of the key ways to ensure diversity of thought and better stakeholder representation. Besides board-level gender representation, ABN Amro also strives to recruit and promote women to senior management positions. Our target for 2014 is to place women in 20 per cent of senior management positions, as well as in 25 per cent of upper middle-management positions.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

Plan-B Icag Pte Ltd

I HAVE been a board member of companies from the public and private sectors for over 30 years now. I subscribe to the principle of board appointments based on the candidate's suitability and not on gender. Based on this, more women who can add to the diversity of background, experience and expertise for the proper and effective functioning of boards should be appointed.

All things being equal, the gender mix of boards should reflect that of the population and working population. There is no reason why it is not so. I contend that much of the imbalance is due to the old boys' network of board appointments. Until this preference or practice is done away with, the status quo will continue for some time. Gender diversity should not be the business of corporate boards. I am for the soft approach to use persuasive power, perhaps even peer pressure, to redress the sharp gender imbalance. If this does not work, legislation or quotas should then be implemented to drive the change, to put more women on boards, as has been shown by some Scandinavian countries.

Ingrid Sidiadinoto

Managing Director

UPS Singapore

BEING in the business of linking people, cultures and commerce, diversity has always been key to UPS. As a woman myself, I am proud to be part of a company that embraces values of inclusiveness and respect, and believes in ensuring equal opportunities for all.

UPS is committed to nurturing our talents by providing various training programmes. In 2010, UPS Singapore was the first in Asia-Pacific to launch the Women's Leadership Development initiative. The programme targets not just women but all employees, women and men alike, by creating a holistic view at providing opportunities for all to develop leadership skills and connect personally and professionally. It appreciates the benefits of gender differences when solving problems, brainstorming and defining processes together.

The initiative aims to improve retention of women at managerial levels, develop women on the management team, and position UPS for future business growth opportunities with women entrepreneurs. It allows us to address the unique challenges women may have working in our industry, but more importantly ensures that we enrich our pipeline of talent for high-level positions, regardless of gender.

Venkatraman Sheshashayee

Chief Executive Officer / Executive Director

Jaya Holdings Ltd

WHILE I respect and appreciate the efforts of the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) on all fronts and believe that SIAS is a force for good, this is one area where I must differ from their views. As a principle, affirmative action must be taken when there is a historic wrong that needs to be corrected. This action is taken with the objective of preventing the adverse outcomes of past actions to continue indefinitely into the future. Affirmative action also breaks existing paradigms and encourages positive change.

Since time immemorial, women - by virtue of tradition, social mores and misinterpretations of texts - have been denied their place in the sun. They have been classed as weaker, manipulated into support roles, given lower status, and faced discrimination and suppression in diverse overt and covert ways. Discrimination based on race, colour or ethnicity has always been easy to recognise and condemn; gender discrimination is far more insidious and does not get much press. While progress has been made in bringing some balance, we still have a long way to go.

Mandated gender diversity, therefore, is an affirmative action that is needed, not just in Singapore, but across the world. Singapore can and should lead the way. We need to encourage gender diversity and gender sensitivity across the spectrum. While this must not be limited to corporate boards, the corporate world can lead by example. And there is a business case for doing so - research has proven, time and again, that companies with woman directors on their boards enjoy higher returns on equity, superior sales and lower attrition rates.

I believe that, for a finite time-frame, boards must be incentivised to have woman directors. Existing directors must be incentivised to mentor and coach woman successors. Boards must be discouraged from using old-boy networks and encouraged to build rigorous procedures to identify, evaluate and choose directors. Senior woman professionals must be encouraged and incentivised to seek board positions, to stand up and insist on being counted. Existing woman directors, when retiring, must be replaced by other women.

Organisations such as SIAS can set up forums where professionals seeking board positions can register their interest to be considered as candidates. CEOs must encourage senior and middle-management woman employees to participate as observers in board meetings, so that they may learn and prepare themselves. These initiatives in themselves will not solve the issue, but will be steps in the right direction.

As for general diversity, that will follow - research has also proven that gender diversity leads to broader, fairer and more diverse organisations and communities.

Pascal Lambert

Chief Country Officer for Singapore, and

Head of Societe Generale Corporate & Investment Banking for Southeast Asia

Societe Generale Group

DIVERSITY and inclusion are at the top of Societe Generale's human resources agenda and we seek to provide workplace equality between men and women at all levels. The bank has set itself a number of objectives in order to continually develop diversity, including a plan to increase the number of female executive staff.

At our headquarters in France, women make up nearly 60 per cent of our employees and over 43 per cent of managers. In Asia, the numbers are 44 per cent and 25 per cent respectively. We are very proud of the fact that we are the only company listed on the CAC40 to have a representation of women of over 20 per cent at every level of the bank, from line staff all the way to the board of directors.

Societe Generale is supportive of all initiatives to increase the participation of women on boards, including the provision of training and inclusion of the issue within the Code of Corporate Governance best practices.

Robert Wilkes

Managing Director - Singapore

Towers Watson

ADVANCING women to positions of leadership is a smart business decision. The presence of different points of view allows management to make informed decisions, which can only happen when you have people from different backgrounds and experience. Companies that have female directors and executives lead by example. It sends a clear message that they value diverse perspectives and experience.

On the Towers Watson board, our lead independent director, Linda Rabbitt, actively champions the advancement of women within Towers Watson. As a member of the board's nominating and governance committee, she inspires our senior executives to continue to expand and strengthen our diversity and inclusion efforts. She also helped set up ''On the Board'', an innovative programme that prepares women for public company board service. We believe board diversity is critical to fuelling innovation, leads to better decision-making and can enhance the company brand in the markets they serve.

George McFerran

Managing Director, Apac

eFinancialCareers

WHEN it comes to diversity, many financial services professionals in Singapore echo the concerns about gender imbalance in the boardroom. In fact a recent survey by eFinancialCareers revealed that over six in ten (62 per cent) believe women are under-represented at the board level. While the issue is widely recognised, experts remain divided on a solution. But professionals in financial services generally agree that workplace flexibility and improved gender diversity policies are the key to women climbing the corporate ladder.

Many firms are already aware of the need to improve gender diversity and the vast majority have good initiatives in place. What this suggests is that to achieve real results, the responsibility for gender diversity extends further than the corporate board. Initiatives need to be promoted more effectively and implemented from entry level. Almost half (48 per cent) of financial services professionals say that gender diversity is very important to them when choosing a future employer - this means that organisations that can show a commitment to diversity will be able to attract the best talent as well as get women to the top.

Leong Yee May

Senior Vice-President

Orange Business Services Asia Pacific

DIVERSITY is integral to business. I believe that social, cultural and gender diversity is a powerful driver of the company's performance, innovation capacity, and attractiveness as an employer. Embracing diversity and providing equal opportunity helps attract and retain clients, apart from building loyalty among our employees. It has also improved our company's efficiency and performance.

Orange is committed to ensuring gender parity, not just at board level, but throughout our workforce. We are doing this through gender-balanced hiring programmes and by providing equal opportunity to both genders across all levels within the organisation. In 2013, one-third of board members, and one-quarter of executive committee members at Orange, were women. We hope to raise this to 35 per cent across all management positions by 2015. While we encourage a culture based on merit, we are aware of social deterrents that can impact gender diversity at the workplace. Hence, we encourage female students to learn more about technical and leadership roles through ''shadowing programmes''. In 2012, more than 60 students shadowed Orange's female engineers and technicians in the US, India, Singapore, and elsewhere, to learn more about their day-to-day work.

In Singapore's context, ensuring diversity on corporate boards cannot take place overnight but any hindrance to equal opportunity must be removed. Businesses should encourage diversity and overcome any social barriers or traditional mindsets. They could include proactive measures to draw women with leadership potential into ''talent pools'', as well as mentoring programmes for women with managerial aspirations. In the long run, corporations should also carry out periodic assessments to ensure roles, responsibilities and remuneration are proportional and without any bias. We need to build a workplace that is based on merit and does not favour any gender, race or community.

Hari V Krishnan

Managing Director

LinkedIn Asia Pacific & Japan

IT's always good to solve a problem before it becomes a problem.

Solving the issue of gender diversity at the top echelons of a company requires a look at downstream factors that may disrupt the careers of female employees when they are holding junior to middle management responsibilities. For example, at these points in their careers, they may be thinking of having children. Our study shows that two of out three women in Singapore plan to put their careers on hold when they have a child, 50 per cent higher than the global average. Clearly, having a more conducive environment that encourages women to return to work after having children will be critical.

Few would disagree that diversity in business is good for business. This is a view shared by many of our clients whenever we discuss talent issues. After all, an inclusive company that embraces diversity across many dimensions such as age, gender, ethnicity, skills and philosophies, will be more responsive to the needs of a wider group of stakeholders and clients.

Max Loh

Country Managing Partner

Ernst & Young LLP

DIVERSITY is fundamentally about the value of the different perspectives that individuals can contribute as a result of their experiences, qualifications and other attributes that define them. Gender is but just one factor in the diversity mix. Given that the board is collectively responsible for the company's long-term strategy and success, and if we accept that diversity drives rigour in thinking and decision-making that can lead to improved corporate performance, then diversity - including that of gender - ought to be the business of boards.

Ensuring diversity should not fall prey to a ''tick-the-box'' exercise. Quotas serve little value if the spirit of inclusion is absent or challenges to established thinking are dismissed quickly. As a start, instilling the discipline to develop a skills matrix, and establishing and continually reviewing directors' experience and expertise that align with the business strategy, will be key, as this will underpin the company's ability to ensure board diversity as well as communicate its board composition and renewal to shareholders with confidence.

Ronald Lee

Managing Director

PrimeStaff Management Services Pte Ltd

I AM all for gender diversity and this is evident from the number of women in our senior management team at PrimeStaff.

While I certainly support initiatives that will help increase the regrettably low proportion of women directors on corporate boards, I don't believe that it should be mandated via legislation or quotas. Forcing companies to put women on their boards will be counter-productive and work against the women in the long run, as doing so just to hit the quota may propagate a perception that they are less deserving and thus defeat the purpose entirely.

In my view, gender diversity is not necessarily the business of corporate boards. However, it is the corporation's duty to ensure that its policies enable all qualified individuals to be given equal opportunity for consideration based on the individual's merits. Prescriptive measures aside, this issue also has to do with cultural norms where corporate boards are still largely perceived to be a ''boys' club'' in Singapore.

Corporations should address the root of the issue and find ways to create a paradigm shift among their top management - to dismantle this perception and be more open to welcoming women into the C-suite and ultimately, onto their boards. Only then will the right foundation be laid for lasting cultural change to take hold.

David Crammond

Founder & CEO

Maachu Pte Ltd

NOT too long ago, men dominated corporate boards with hardly any woman alongside. Over time, it has been proven that having women on corporate boards has provided a different dimension and this is valuable to businesses.

Drawing from my experience in Canada where I used to live, gender diversity is clearly the responsibility of the board. They must be the initiator by creating an environment where the search for talent ''naturally'' includes female professionals from the outset. Too often, it is an afterthought introduced to ensure the appearance of gender balance. This is a disservice to the more than capable female executives. To ensure diversity in any aspect of life, the starting point needs to be a goal. As in education, or employment, quotas in Singapore are widely implemented and should also be rolled out at board level for gender diversity.

At Maachu, when we invite applications for senior positions, we are ''gender blind'' as it should be the best person for the job and not based on gender preference. This should also apply to corporate boards.

Yeoh Oon Jin

Executive Chairman

PwC Singapore

AS businesses become more global and complex, companies need to attract talent who think differently and can adopt a variety of approaches to problem-solving.

Organisations need to attract these diverse talent - whether it is diversity in gender, age, ethnicity or other competencies, not only for the board director level but also at the staff level. A lack of diverse talent could inhibit a company's growth.

To ensure that companies select the best directors, boards should ensure that they source for potential candidates from as wide a talent pool as possible. Studies have shown that a diverse board will reduce the amount of groupthink, produce better results and promote good corporate governance, all essential attributes of an effective board.

Nominating committees play a key role in composing a board with different perspectives, experiences and skillsets who can work collectively for the good of the company. Its role includes ensuring it identifies the technical competencies required for the board in addition to other diverse capabilities, and that they screen for these attributes. Thus it is essential to cast their net wide and deep when looking for such candidates.

Natalie Shuman

Senior Vice-President, General Manager, EMEA & Apac

Kelly Services

THE responsibility to ensure gender diversity extends beyond the boardroom. In fact, the shortage of female board directors is more likely to be solved by building gender diversity in providing sufficient opportunities for women to reach leadership positions, rather than introducing quotas or laws. We should educate companies to help them understand that gender diversity impacts economic performance, growth and profitability. Having good intentions about seeing women in leadership is insufficient; identifying barriers and putting concrete actions in place to achieve the desired results is imperative.

At Kelly, taking a conscious approach has resulted in women now accounting for a third of Kelly's senior executives and 36 per cent of the board (up from 17 per cent a decade ago). We have a women business resource group - Leadership in Action (LIA), Powered by the Women in Kelly - that is open to both male and female leaders within Kelly to contribute their ideas and shape the company's business strategy. LIA also serves as an opportunity to build our internal leadership pipeline and has a significant impact on the development of leaders in the company.

Emma Dale

Co-Founder and Managing Director (Asia)

Prospect Resourcing

WHEN introducing gender diversity in any setting, it's important not to view it as a women-only agenda. Gender diversity is about the proven business results to be gained from having a more gender-diverse workforce. At present board positions in Asia are dominated by men but having women at the top table would most certainly add value. A recent study, titled Singapore Board Diversity Report 2013: Time for Women to Rise, showed that organisations with women on the board saw a positive effect on performance in terms of return on assets and return on equity.

Recruitment plays a crucial role in gender diversity. Educating line managers about the benefits of a gender-diverse team as well as having the right hiring processes in place can minimise gender bias from the very beginning. When it comes to succession planning, having a more equal balance of men and women will naturally produce a talent pool of future leaders that's more reflective of society.

Robin C Lee

Group COO

Bok Seng Group

THE primary criterion of selecting members for the board of companies is hardly about women's rights or even things such as racial diversity, but rather about ensuring that the best decisions are made in the boardrooms for all stakeholders. Yes, I feel that having more women would definitely be a benefit as there would be a larger spectrum of perspectives leading to a holistic approach to achieving the best results.

Diversity, however, is not just based on being a man or woman; it is also about diversity in knowledge, background, training, expertise and experience. It is therefore vital to ensure that a board encompasses a good mix of professionals with such multifarious background. Across society here, meritocracy rises above many other aspects where talent engagement is concerned and the corporate setting should be no different. Therefore, as much as a company desires to assemble a team of board members with diverse views and contributions, they should first ensure that they select members in a manner that places such merits above all else.

Daniel Soh

Managing Partner

Leadership Advisory Inc

THE decision on who should be nominated to serve on the board is now more considered, in terms of adding value and experience. For companies to be competitive, they need to plan strategically and think ''out of the box'' about their board composition. To build a more diverse board, the nominating committee must be willing to look beyond the traditional pools of talent tapped for corporate boards and present a diverse panel of potential candidates. This should include C-suite executives who are successful professionals and entrepreneurs, or even functional specialists, which the current board may not be familiar or less comfortable with.

The process should start with the perspective for a more diverse board and a clear strategy. Diversity should not be taken out of a sense of fairness. It should ensure that the ''best candidates'' are brought together to address the challenges. Corporate boards at many companies have dramatically improved their handling of CEO succession planning, with a view on both internal and external prospective candidates. Addressing their attention to gender diversity could be one of their hardest challenges.

Christophe Duchatellier

CEO

Adecco Asia

DIVERSITY is the business of corporate boards. A diverse workforce benefits the organisation in various ways, including a range of talents and expertise. A diverse organisation also encourages an open and inclusive corporate culture that's helpful not only for growing the bottom line but also in promoting employer branding and talent retention.

The way we look at diversity determines the way we view talent. Diversity is a necessity in the modern workplace and it has to be embedded in the way we recruit, train, promote and also the way we do business. Ensuring gender diversity must be a concerted effort. Whether it is externally hiring a female top talent or recruiting and promoting organically, companies must invest in building roadmaps for high potentials, specifically designed to attract women, including mentoring and coaching programmes.

Brad Adams

Head of HR Research & Product Management in Asia

CEB

OUR view is that the notion of diverse board leaders as ''Diversity Heroes'' is simply insufficient. While diversity at the board level is important, for companies to truly capitalise on diversity, an inclusive mindset is required across the entire workforce.

Our data shows that diverse and inclusive companies get better results; they have employees who work 12 per cent harder, are 19 per cent more likely to stay, and collaborate up to 57 per cent more effectively. In addition, our research shows that while 80 per cent of executives support diversity and inclusion initiatives, less than half of Singapore workers think their organisation is diverse or inclusive. To improve workforce diversity and inclusion, organisations must firstly make broad diversity goals and inclusive behaviour real for managers and employees in the context of their daily work and, secondly, assess and reward for progress, not goal achievement.

Leong Soo Yee

Head

ACCA Singapore

AS the agents of shareholders, the board of directors forms one of the pillars of a robust corporate governance framework. Diversifying the board, including greater gender diversity, is one of the ways to strengthen corporate governance. ACCA research also found that gender diversity encourages innovation, creativity and productive collaboration. While recent trends in board appointments indicate a positive shift towards more female directorships, more can still be done in support for greater diversity. Corporate boards should therefore ensure that gender diversity is high on the agenda.

Corporations should take a multi-pronged approach to ensure that their boards are broadly diverse. Companies are encouraged to establish a formal search and nomination process for board appointments as suggested by the Diversity Task Force as this would allow them to achieve the appropriate diversity of competencies and gender.

Where there are imbalances on the board, whether male or female, suitable candidates could be identified from available databases and listings objectively and training be required to be given to these candidates to ensure that they function effectively in the board. Lastly, a change in mindset may be necessary in order to welcome and accept a more heterogeneous board. This would require a concerted effort by the board to change corporate culture, if necessary.

Philippe HJ Huinck

Regional Managing Director, South and South East Asia

International SOS

LAST year, McKinsey reported that nearly half of Fortune 1,000 companies have just one or no woman in C-suite positions. Despite this statistic, the gender imbalance has improved greatly from previous years when there were hardly any women on corporate boards. Studies have also showed the positive link between companies that have embraced gender diversity and improved financial performance.

Still, the principle of having more women in the boardroom should not be inculcated through quotas or incentives. Such mandatory adoption, as seen in some countries in Europe, could prove counter-productive in the search for top talent. Instead, companies need to recognise the benefits of gender-diverse teams and develop a hiring strategy that encourages diversity while still ensuring board appointments are based on merit.

Mixed-gender boards typically perform better in terms of problem-solving through the presentation of a wider variety of viewpoints, ideas and market insights which in turn offer superior information-based decision-making. In this respect, women board members are no different from their male counterparts in being able to contribute critical skillsets such as management experience and functional expertise.

International SOS was recently presented with the TAFEP Exemplary Employer Award 2014 for Outstanding Inclusive Workplace Culture. We have a strong representation of women throughout our ranks including in senior positions such as country general managers and on executive committees. Any staff member who epitomises our core values (Passion, Expertise, Care and Respect) and displays consistent excellent performance, is given an opportunity for career advancement including into senior leadership roles.

Paul Endacott

Managing Director, SEA

Ambition Group Ltd

GENDER diversity is and should be the business of corporate boards, just as it is the responsibility of the senior management in an organisation. For an organisation to promote gender diversity, it needs to lead by example and this is reflected in having a diverse board.

The benefits that gender diversity brings to the organisation need to be recognised and emphasised by the company through its recruitment and promotion strategy, and there needs to be a commitment to achieving this diversity across the organisation too. With the right balance between quota and meritocracy, gender diversity is definitely something that is achievable by all boards.

Lee Fook Chiew

Chief Executive Officer

Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants

THE benefits of board diversity to good corporate governance have been well-documented. Having board members with diverse backgrounds and experience promotes fresh perspectives, healthy debate and board independence. There is thus merit to promoting gender diversity on corporate boards. However it should be one out of many factors when considering board composition and should not be pursued for its own sake.

To promote board diversity in general, companies can consider setting a diversity policy for their board. They can also conduct self-assessment to identity the gaps in skills and experience in their current board, and use that as a basis for recruiting new members to the board. Creating a culture that embraces diversity and is open to new board members is equally important.

Michael Smith

Country Director

Randstad Singapore

THE Randstad World of Work 2013/14 report revealed that although 62 per cent of employers surveyed say more women in leadership roles will be a critical success factor for their organisations, only 15 per cent of them look to recruit more women. This is alarming as organisations that do not encourage gender diversity would not only narrow the pool of available talent, but also miss out the unique perspectives and business acumen that female employees can bring.

To ensure gender diversity, it is key for business leaders to make diversity a priority and take measurable actions from the top, including the CEO and the board, and throughout the organisation. Organisations need to build an organisational structure and value proposition that supports diversity, for example, adopt flexible working options to help employees to achieve worklife balance and provide mentors to fast-track women into leadership roles.

Julienne Loh

General Manager, Singapore

MasterCard Worldwide

IT's admirable that the Diversity Action Committee is working with various stakeholders to create a conducive environment that helps encourage support for women on boards. As a global business with a good gender mix on our board and in executive management, we regard diversity as the root of innovation. We believe that diversity of culture, experience and thought all drives innovative thinking.

MasterCard surveys have found that Singaporeans consistently believe more support - from employers, better representation in government, better access to home help and better maternity and paternity leave - is key to enabling and empowering women to excel and advance in their chosen roles. However, the ultimate goal should be appointing the right people for the right positions, so that companies reap the most benefits.

Dora Hoan

Co-Chairman / Group CEO

Best World International Ltd

RUNNING a board has less to do with gender than ability. Board members can come from diverse backgrounds - they can be part of the companies' management teams or they can be major shareholders or professionals. No matter their backgrounds, they have to possess the capability to be elected to the board.

That said, having women on the board would be beneficial. They can offer different perspectives as well as maintain harmony among the members. However, corporations should not deliberately choose board members using gender (or gender ratio) as a requirement.

Sam Yap

Group Executive Chairman and Co-Founder

Htwo Investment Holdings Pte Ltd

I SUPPORT the Diversity Task Force's recommendation to adopt a soft approach to try to redress the sharp gender imbalance. Rather than recommending legislation or mandatory quotas on female directorship, the preference to use persuasive power to get companies to put more women on their boards is wise. The bottom line is to ensure that the board comprises people who can get the company going up to higher levels and that they can provide good leadership in the implementation of the company's policies. Nothing to do with gender! There should be a spirit of meritocracy.

I also agree that boards must be diverse in all aspect, not just in gender. Women who are appointed to boards must be of a certain calibre and capability comparable to their male counterparts. They should be able to contribute on their own merits. They should not be appointed as directors solely because of their gender or to meet a quota requirement. Ultimately from a business point of view, the members of the board, whether male or female, must be able to bring value to the entire business.

Chris Hill

CEO - SE Asia

Black Sun Pte Ltd

THE statistics will ultimately be driven by education demographics, immigration trends and social mobility, making board diversity unavoidable. However, the view expressed by SIAS is not reflected internationally, particularly in the EU and UK where both public sentiment and regulation have played an active role in board diversity trends. Black Sun conducts annual research into corporate reporting trends of the FTSE 100 companies, now in its eighth year of publication. In our most recent analysis of annual reports in 2013, it was evident that companies were showing an improvement in gender balance. This has been driven by a combination of persuasion and regulation.

In 2011 the Lord Davies Review on gender diversity was released, which recommended - not required - that boards should aim for 25 per cent female representation by 2015. This, coupled with the new regulatory requirements of the UK Companies Act 2006 (Strategic Report and Directors Report Regulations 2013) to report the number of males and females on the board, senior management and the organisation as a whole, appears to be driving progress.

Black Sun data shows that 93 per cent of FTSE 100 boards have female representation, up from 78 per cent three years before. Progress has also been made in both executive and non-executive areas, with 19 per cent of companies having female executives, up from 17 per cent in the prior year, and the number of female non-executives increasing to 89 per cent, up from 72 per cent three years earlier. In addition, FTSE 100 companies continue to disclose their board diversity policies, with 63 per cent doing this up from 56 per cent in the prior year. This increased focus on reporting board diversity policies, having to report the gender mix and the recommendations from the Lord Davies Review has helped to focus the minds of companies and ultimately led them to focus on the female talent pipeline. Therefore it seems entirely plausible that female representation will keep increasing. Of note, 31 per cent of companies already reached the target set in the Lord Davies Review, up from 13 per cent in the prior year.

From our experience in Europe, the focus on board diversity in government debates, the media, institutional investor discussions and regulatory reforms has led corporates to react and make gender diversity the business of boards and ensure that they not only factor this into their succession planning, but report back to explain their approach to ensuring diversity of the business and how this will benefit strategic decision-making going forward.

Jessica Tan

Managing Director

Microsoft Singapore

I AGREE that gender diversity is the business of corporate boards. But I do believe this is more than just a question of having more women in leadership positions. In today's fast-paced and competitive landscape, the importance of having a diverse pool of talents - regardless of gender, creed, race or age - and an inclusive workplace cannot be over-emphasised because it could potentially impact the company's talent base and long-term future.

By embracing the diversity of their talents, companies can benefit from the breadth of perspectives, skills and experiences that would enable them to be more innovative in the products and services they develop, and successfully serve the needs of an increasingly global and diverse customer and partner base. Similarly, having an inclusive environment where all talents are given equal opportunities to succeed will ensure that companies can attract, develop and retain their best talents, for the success of their businesses.

Daniel Rudolph

President

Henkel Singapore

AT Henkel, gender is an important pillar of our diversity strategy. For our consumer products especially, women are key direct or indirect users. In order to meet their needs, it is important for us to reflect this audience within Henkel's employee structure.

Women have also become a key talent resource. In Henkel, the share of women in management positions rose from 26 per cent in 2008 to around 32 per cent at the end of 2013. Henkel has a chairwoman on the supervisory board and a woman on the management board. We invest in developing our talented female employees and helping them realise their leadership potential. While the call for women in leadership positions is loud and sustained, Henkel is against a fixed female quota. Irrespective of gender, everyone is assessed and promoted based on their performance and potential.

Mark Billington

Regional Director, South East Asia

ICAEW

DESPITE being a progressive and high-income economy with women making up half of its labour force, gender diversity remains a challenge in Singapore's boardrooms. Women continue to be under-represented and it is the role of the government as well as corporate boards to actively encourage greater female participation in leadership roles.

In this aspect, Singapore could look towards Malaysia which promotes women in leadership positions as contributing towards progress for organisations and the nation. It has set a national agenda of increasing female participation in decision-making positions to 30 per cent by 2016. ICAEW is supporting this effort with a recently launched Women in Leadership programme that provides leadership development for Malaysian women aiming to take up leadership positions. This is something that could be emulated in Singapore, along with an introduction of effective work-life balance policies that could support women in juggling work and family responsibilities - a key obstacle women often struggle with in career advancement.

More female representation is one aspect of diversity but what is also important is to ensure diversity in thinking as well as in personnel. Boards need to be diverse not just in appearance but also in substance; they need to be open to all views and perspectives.

Roland Smith

Vice-President and Managing Director, Apac

Centre for Creative Leadership

YES, the lack of gender diversity is absolutely a matter that should be addressed by corporate boards. This is especially alarming since men and women in Singapore both have equal educational opportunities and equally high literacy rates (98 per cent for men and 94 per cent for women, according to official data).

Corporations should provide equal opportunities for capable women to be groomed as leaders. In fact, research has shown that the feminine style of leadership (being more empathetic, humane and relationship-oriented) is more effective in modern organisations.

Corporations can promote an environment that provides equal access to special assignments and training programmes, keeping track on women talent, and providing flexibility to women with family responsibilities. They can also encourage the formation of formal or informal associations, where female colleagues provide mutual support for each other. Women tend to be more relationship-oriented and are often team players, and hence networks like these are a great resource of support.

Zaheer Merchant

Regional Director (Singapore & Europe)

QI Group of Companies

THE McKinsey study, Moving mind-sets on gender diversity, found that female executives were equally capable and ambitious, but that their confidence to reach the top echelons depended more on a strong and supportive corporate culture, and support from the top management in particular. Clearly, as such, meritocratic values and inculcated inclusiveness in a seemingly male-dominated space are key to ensuring board diversity. This is not an alien concept and is achievable by creating awareness and emphasising the eventual benefits that diversity brings.

These benefits are broadly evident in things such as enhanced client insights, strong performance on both financial and non-financial indicators and, in part, improved board effectiveness as evident from studies such as The Business Case for Women on Boards. That said, I subscribe to the belief that the politics of diversity has no place being the ''business'' of the board. It helps, but it cannot be an overarching factor that a board makes it a significant concern over actual business matters. This would be disingenuous to stakeholders (as much as to either gender) as it would seem that any appointment finds possible ulterior motives over reality - which is the election of the best person in the correct chair. In my view, by creating awareness, boards will serve and ensure in time that the adage ''the best (wo)man for the job'' becomes truly gender-neutral.

David Leong

Managing director

PeopleWorldwide Consulting Pte Ltd

BOARD diversity is not just about gender diversity; that woud be too restrictive and narrow a perspective. It is really not the business of the board to be gender-sensitive to the point where the nominating committee must consider gender diversity as part of the equation for balance. The business of the board is to ensure that it has all the competency and capabilities to discharge its duties properly.

The board must select its members first on character, competencies and capabilities in a specific domain. The lack of women on boards is probably due more to the relatively fewer number of women in senior positions to form a sizeable pool to select from. This can be addressed by training women for directorship and having a register to show area of expertise, industry and availability for board nominations. It is more a supply-demand dissonance than any deliberate effort to keep the board to an all-male bastion.

The board must constantly be seeking diversity in its structure so that groupthink can be reduced and quality of representation can be enhanced. Diversity must not be looked at through the lens of discrimination and biases, but from a point where diversity will add strengths to decision-making since the views come from various angles.

Women's representation on board is still sorely lacking and it must be generally agreed that they bring about a different blend of thought leadership, command and control. As evidenced from the corporate and political arenas where women hold sway, matriarchal leadership is equally powerful. Question is where can we find enough of these leaders? Like the song by Peter, Paul and Mary, where have all the flowers gone, long time passing?

I hope an open register of trained and certified directors at the Singapore Institute of Directors or Singapore Exchange will help open doors for diversity. Not just gender but all aspects of diversity.

Patrick Liew

Managing Partner

Global Enterprise Exchange

THERE is compelling evidence to suggest that gender diversity can enhance a corporate board's monitoring function and improve the company's financial value and performance. However, to have a positive effect, it depends on the strategic intent of the company, corporate culture, and the way key stakeholders relate and interact with one another.

For example, research by Renee B Adams and Daniel Ferreira showed that having a more diverse board should not place added stress on existing infrastructure. It should not also incur additional expenses to induce cooperation, including having additional board meetings and performance-based pay.

Therefore, before implementing a gender diversity policy, the company has to educate its stakeholders about preference- or perception-based discrimination. There may be a need to change negative cultural norms and gender stereotypes.

In some cases, the old-boy network may have to accommodate and adapt to a different style of operation. It has to be open-minded and learn that there may be a better way to serve on a corporate board.

Mystery of Malaysian 1MDB's US$2.3b Cayman Islands fund

It still has not given details of the funds or manager's name

Anita Gabriel

Published

Sun, May 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Some US$2.3 billion ($2.9 billion) belonging to Malaysia's state-owned fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB), ploughed into unidentified Cayman Islands funds, is being managed by little-known Hong Kong firm Bridge Partners, The Business Times has learnt.

The revelation comes at a time when 1MDB is under fire for placing funds in hedge funds abroad, particularly since almost all of its assets - power generation and landbank - are based in Malaysia.

The said funds were invested by Malaysia's state-backed fund through Brazen Sky Ltd - a wholly owned unit incorporated in the British Virgin Islands (BVI) - in a segregated portfolio company (SPC) called Bridge Global Absolute Return Fund managed by Bridge Partners, according to documents obtained by this newspaper.

1MDB has also been pressured to reveal the names of the Cayman Island funds and fund manager, but has not done so.

The documents also reveal that, through the SPC, the monies were invested into six classes of shares of unlisted open-ended funds focused on the energy sector.

While Bridge Partners is a licensed fund manager, it is still unclear as to why 1MDB would outsource its monies to such a modest outfit. The move is also at odds with the Malaysian sovereign wealth fund's mandate to drive key projects in its home base and woo foreign investments into Malaysia.

"Why is a state-owned fund hiring a small firm run by a very smallish team to manage its funds which it may not have complete control over?" asked a market watcher.

Based on its website, Bridge Partners, which specialises in offshore private funds, is led by managing director Mr Lobo Lee Kwok Ning, who has 20 years' experience in equity investments and derivatives. He was previously senior vice-president of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd.

The firm's asset management team has two other directors.

Documents also reveal that a Swiss private bank in Singapore produced portfolio statements on these funds, possibly to indicate that the funds are genuine. It is unclear why the bank felt the need to do that, as such reports are typically issued by the fund manager - in this case, Bridge Partners.

Bridge Capital and Brazen Sky first came into the picture two years ago following a convoluted and perplexing tie-up between 1MDB, then helmed by chief executive officer Shahrol Halmi, and obscure firm PetroSaudi International (PSI), headed by Tarek Essam Ahmad Obaid, a Saudi royalty.

1MDB's tie-up with PSI - 1MDB PetroSaudi - is the fund's first joint venture since it was set up in 2009, not too long after it raised RM5 billion ($1.9 billion) through a bond issue.

The Malaysian-backed fund ploughed US$1 billion cash for its 40 per cent into the US$2.5 billion joint venture firm domiciled in BVI. PSI forked out no cash, only oil and gas assets for its 60 per cent share, which according to documents was valued at US$2.7 billion.

Sources said that, in the early stages of the deal, some 1MDB board members were concerned about the value and quality of the assets being injected and had preferred instead for PSI to fork out at least 50 per cent cash for its portion to match 1MDB's cash outlay.

The pact flopped and, following a series of complex manoeuvrings, issuance of Islamic debt facility and asset flippings, 1MDB's wholly-owned 1MDB International Holdings ended up with a 49 per cent stake of PSI's PetroSaudi Oil Services Ltd (PSOSL). The stake was valued at US$2.2 billion.

1MDB then sold all of 1MDB International Holdings, whose sole asset was the PSOSL stake, to Bridge Partners for US$2.3 billion, turning in a profit of some US$95 million.

To satisfy the purchase, Bridge Partners issued six interest-free promissory notes with a one-month expiry data. 1MDB then invested the proceeds by subscribing for all the shares in Brazen Sky, which in turn reinvested the sum into the SPC.

Documents also reveal that Mr Shahrol, 1MDB's then-boss - who left in March last year to join another government unit - had the sole discretion to decide where the funds would be reinvested.

1MDB has been in the line of fire after its latest financial accounts showed that it carried liabilities of some RM40 billion. It also would have been in the red by as much as RM1.8 billion, if not for a RM2.7 billion revaluation gain on land it got from the government.

The fund, chaired by Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, has been dogged by controversy since its inception five years ago and has had to frequently allay fears that the billions of dollars in its coffers - mostly raised through borrowings and ploughed into controversial investments - are safe.

More recently, following calls by the Malaysian media for 1MDB to bring the funds totalling some RM18 billion back to Malaysia, the fund responded by saying that "substantial portions" of the overseas funds have been brought back and used for energy and property projects and earmarked for future investments.

BT's attempts to contact 1MDB and Bridge Partners for comments were unsuccessful.

site_title: Cyber liability insurance to grow
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Cyber liability insurance to grow

Companies' concerns over reputational damage will drive demand, Marsh Singapore CEO Iris Teo tells JAMIE LEE

Published

Sun, May 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MARSH Singapore, the largest insurance broker by market share here, expects demand for cyber liability insurance to grow as companies become more concerned over reputational damage from a cyber attack.

A survey it conducted showed that significantly more companies (65 per cent) this year said reputational damage was their top concern following a cyber attack or data breach, compared to last year (44 per cent).

In spite of this, the take-up of cyber liability insurance has been gradual, said Iris Teo, CEO of Marsh Singapore, in an interview with The Business Times.

She noted that there appears to be some inertia, with just 47 per cent of companies planning to buy or renew cyber liability insurance in the next 12 months - down from 62 per cent a year ago.

But, she added: "Insurance for new and emerging risk areas, such as cyber risk, always requires a longer gestation period. Take-up rates tend to begin slowly, and then accelerate as companies, and the industry, develop a deeper understanding of the area."

Data breach

This was the case in the United States and the United Kingdom, where cyber liability insurance is becoming a common class of business insurance, Ms Teo added. Insurance can cover the whole gamut of risks, from negligence claims, to a loss of revenue from business interruption.

A massive data breach at US retailer Target in December highlighted the damage that can ensue from such an incident. After credit-card details of over 100 million people were stolen, Target said sales were significantly weaker after the breach, as consumers shied away for fear of a repeat incident.

A similar data breach also took place in South Korea.

As for Singapore, Ms Teo said, the gradual take-up of cyber liability insurance could suggest a surge in demand later, as data protection issues here bear greater prominence in the coming months.

This awareness, combined with the full Personal Data Protection Act, or PDPA, coming into effect in July, should prompt companies to examine their risk management and insurance programmes more closely.

"It's encouraging to see the 'it won't happen to me' mindset changing, as companies recognise the new reality of cyber risk in Singapore and across Asia," said Ms Teo.

Greater awareness has also lifted demand for liabilities insurance for directors, she pointed out. As directors become more concerned about the risks of poor corporate governance, they have been more vigilant in checking that companies have them covered.

"Before, if they were invited to the board, they would just feel very honoured," said Ms Teo.

"Now, they ask: 'How much is your director's liability policy?'"

She noted that the more developed a market is, the more litigious it tends to be.

Ms Teo also pointed out other changes in company policies here as Singapore society evolves. Marsh Singapore, which sells insurance directly to companies as well as offers consultation services, has seen companies providing a more flexible suite of benefits.

Businesses here are now looking into healthcare coverage for their employees, particularly as they juggle the costs from higher employee benefits against the need to attract talent.

This means that, instead of providing healthcare coverage alone, companies can provide gym subscriptions or even subsidies for eye care, noted Ms Teo.

"We are encouraging clients to look at wellness programmes," she added.

site_title: Congress clears way for deepening ports
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Congress clears way for deepening ports

Published

Sun, May 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] House and Senate negotiators reached agreement on a bill that would authorise deepening several US ports ahead of the expansion of the Panama Canal and the bigger ships that will use it.

The bill - the first such measure in seven years - will include language that would let ports pay the costs of deepening harbours up front, then seek reimbursement from the government once the project is authorised by lawmakers. That could help facilities that sought the provision, such as Port Everglades in South Florida, reduce construction time by years.

"That's a big part of this bill," House Transportation Committee chairman Bill Shuster, said in an interview. "They've got money ready to go."

The Water Resources Reform and Development Act is seen as one of the few examples of bipartisan action in a polarised Congress that's on pace to become the least productive in history in terms of bills passed.

The full legislation probably won't be released until later this week, Mr Shuster and his Senate Democratic counterpart, Barbara Boxer of California, said in a joint statement.

The Senate-passed version would have authorised money to take action in response to rising sea levels or increased ocean temperatures resulting from global warming.

House Republicans who have resisted new spending linked to climate change rejected that provision.

Even so, Senate majority leader Harry Reid, a Democrat, said the agreement contains language about the effect of global warming on sea levels and ocean temperatures.

The final sticking point in the talks was over a proposed National Endowment for Oceans that Mr Shuster said was dropped.

The largest navigation project included in both the House and Senate-passed measures would deepen the Sabine-Neches Waterway, which connects the oil-refining hub of Beaumont and Port Arthur, Texas, with the Gulf of Mexico.

The Port Arthur area is home to the southern end of the Keystone XL pipeline. Deepening the port will reduce shipping costs for oil and natural gas processed there by Exxon Mobil, Total and Cheniere Energy.

That deepening project was included in the final bill, Mr Shuster said, along with more than two dozen others. For Port Evergalades the measure could bring as much as US$181 million.

Also authorised, Mr Shuster said, are storm and flood prevention projects, including the Morganza to the Gulf levee system sought by lawmakers in storm-battered Louisiana and a diversion channel for the Red River of the North that would reduce flood risks in Fargo, the largest city in North Dakota.

The final language will be released this week, negotiators said in a joint statement. The House could take up the bill as early as the week of May 19. - WP

site_title: EY: Firms need to raise cybersecurity readiness
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

EY: Firms need to raise cybersecurity readiness

Lack of skilled security specialists has contributed to the problem. VICTORIA HO reports

Published

Sun, May 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MOST companies in the Asia-Pacific are poorly prepared for cybersecurity breaches, and as more threats become focused - targeted attacks on individual firms - an intrusion would likely catch most victims flat-footed, according to cybercrime watchers at EY (formerly Ernst & Young). Massimo Cotrozzi, assistant director of fraud investigation and dispute services for EY in the UK and Ireland, said that in his work with companies, he has discovered that the level of cybersecurity preparedness has not been up to snuff.

The past eight years or so has seen companies building protection plans covering hypothetical threats. But companies that are leading in security are talking about the impact on their businesses due to threats over the past few years, rather than discuss risk.

"In general, companies that have found that they were compromised at some point, didn't realise they were at the time," he said, adding that this knowledge gap is due to the lack of skilled security specialists that companies can hire.

Lawrance Lai, partner with EY's fraud investigation department in Singapore, said that local companies are displaying a "marked change in sentiment" when it comes to cybersecurity - they are far less blasé about it, and are no longer simply guarding against potential attacks. "They are channelling their energies towards developing a proactive stance, because they realise that threats are becoming increasingly complex, and require advanced (tools)."

It's no wonder that the Singapore government has elevated cyber-security to a top-level concern, he noted.

The government has set up a five-year cyber-security master plan that focuses on buffing up IT infrastructure, and investing in growing the pool of personnel with specialised skills. "Cybercrime is a key priority on the national agenda. As a global financial hub, Singapore is not spared from the increasing threat of attack."

Mr Cotrozzi pointed out that security staff need to be competent in IT forensics, but they also need to be keenly tapped into business processes so that they know how to catch intrusions, or know how intrusions would take down a business.

"Every security system is different. You need to understand the logic of the (overall) system," he said.

He added that companies keen to crank their preparedness up a notch should start by rewriting the processes in place to deal with intrusions, he said.

Consider the tools needed and what the company already uses, in an overhead view of the organisation, he advised. Often, companies rely on a panoply of tools that have been cobbled together over the years, but do not form a cohesive defence when put together.

"One of our clients had anti-virus software for incoming mail, and border security as an outer ring defence," he said. But the IT department didn't make the logical link between the two, and didn't realise that the anti-virus having to catch malware meant that the border security outside it had failed.

"The security processes were not in place to flag these incidents," he said.

It's tough for companies because security tools available in the market aren't as intelligent as companies would need for advanced threats, he said. "Analytics (and big data) software companies are just starting to integrate security into their intelligence products."

Furthermore, security software that is too enthusiastic in blocking threats become hindrances to workers, who find they have to jump through too many hoops to get something done, Mr Cotrozzi added.

This results in workers removing or bypassing the security products in an effort to be productive. "Companies don't want to risk losing business because of security," he said, on companies removing their security software or keeping vigilance levels low.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

OCBC offers cash transfer via Facebook

Free mobile banking service allows $100 a day to be sent to any bank account here

Published Mon, May 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

IF you were going to cull people from your Facebook friends' list, you might want to hold off until they have paid up for, say, a drinks tab rung up some six months ago. OCBC has now made it possible for its customers to instantly send as much as $100 daily to any bank account in Singapore through a link via Facebook, a phone number, or an e-mail address. It is the first bank in Singapore to provide this free service, which was launched yesterday through an update of its mobile banking application.

Unlike the current payment system, the sender will not need the recipient's bank account number to transfer the money. To use this service, the sender picks the "pay anyone" option from the mobile banking app. He selects the mode of communication - phone, e-mail, or Facebook - and then accesses his OCBC banking account. After keying in the amount to be transferred, the user inputs a passcode and a one-time password for the funds transfer to be completed.

site_title: SIA plans new cabin class, sticks by Tiger
content:
SIA plans new cabin class, sticks by Tiger

It'll launch premium economy on medium-to-long-haul flights in the middle of next year

Published

Fri, May 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) is not giving up on wounded Tiger Airways, and is also fighting back with a premium economy class on its own brand.

"As a shareholder, we would certainly want to demand that Tiger work out some plan to see how it can turn around, and I think the Tiger board and management want to do it too," SIA chief executive Goh Choon Phong told the media on the sidelines of a post-earnings briefing yesterday. "So there is clearly an interest from both parties to want to improve the situation."

Tiger, in which SIA has a 40 per cent stake, booked its third straight year of losses last week, reporting that it was $223 million in the red. Days after that, the budget carrier's chief executive, Koay Peng Yen, stepped down. SIA Cargo president Lee Lik Hsin is slated to replace him on Monday.

Asked about the possibilities of privatising Tiger or actively increasing SIA's stake in the budget carrier, Mr Goh said: "At this point in time, there is no plan of that sort. Our main concern and focus is to see how Tiger can turn around."

Yesterday, SIA also announced that it would launch a premium economy class in the middle of next year. It will be introduced on the Boeing 777-300ERs, and then on the Airbus A380s.

According to SIA executive vice-president commercial Mak Swee Wah, this new class is meant for the medium-to-long-haul flights. It will be aimed at a mix of leisure and corporate travellers who want a bit more comfort than in economy class.

"There is a niche there that is quite established in the market now. We are now designing the product to fit that segment and we will come up with something that will be interesting," Mr Mak said.

This additional space is going to come out of economy class. "We will have to take out some economy class (seats), but at the end of the day, premium economy is a product that we think can command a better premium than the equivalent economy."

UOB Kay Hian analyst K Ajith said the move carries the risk of cannibalising SIA's business class product, but also noted that the airline has little choice, given stiff competition and how other airlines already have similar offerings. "But they could, of course, price it in such a way that there is still a differential. Typically, business class seats before promotions can generally be 3-5 times that of economy. SIA could price the premium economy seats 100-150 per cent higher than economy class on routes where there's less competition," he said.

About a decade ago, SIA had a similar class option in place, billed as "executive economy", on its non-stop flights to the United States. These seats were phased out in 2008 for an all-business-class configuration.

On Thursday, SIA reported a Q4 operating loss that widened year-on-year to $60.3 million. Had it not been for large tax credits and exceptional gains, its quarterly bottom line would have been red, too. Even so, the group is doubling down. It said yesterday it will spend US$325 million to retrofit the cabins of 19 Boeing 777-300ERs, starting in early 2015 and completed by September 2016.

Last July, a unit was set up within the group to examine ways to grow revenue through other channels apart from ticket sales. This "new revenue unit" already has several ongoing initiatives, such as the involvement of commission-based third-party products and advertising.

"We have undisclosed but ambitious targets for this unit to meet," Mr Goh said.

site_title: Oracle taps growth of the cloud
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Oracle taps growth of the cloud

It's offering hundreds of business apps with launch of Oracle cloud marketplace

Published

Sun, May 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE cloud is allowing companies achieve lower costs, improve quality of service and customer satisfaction, and achieve a faster time to market with new capabilities. This is changing the way they do business. In Singapore, 66 per cent of companies surveyed for a global cloud study last year indicated that one of the key benefits of the cloud is lower TCO (total cost of ownership).

In view of this, enterprise software vendor Oracle is offering a slew of cloud products to suit customer needs. Speaking to BizIT, Sanjay Sinha, vice president for product development at Oracle, noted that in order to address customer needs, Oracle launched the Oracle cloud marketplace at Oracle OpenWorld last year.

"The explosive growth of cloud, mobile, and social technologies is driving the need for organisations to gain faster and easier access to innovative and trusted business applications. Oracle cloud marketplace offers a one-stop shop of solutions for customers looking for a way to extend their suite of applications.

"It features hundreds of business applications developed by Oracle partners, enabling Oracle cloud customers to easily browse, evaluate, and license trusted business applications," Mr Sinha, who is based in the US, said.

He added that giving customers the power to choose business applications to suit their needs remains the key element for enterprise software purchasing. "Customers have a choice in purchasing and deploying applications - using established business practices for on-premise applications in conjunction with using the Oracle marketplace for cloud deployment."

Mr Sinha added that cloud computing is driving a significant part of Oracle's product development plans and is a key part of its strategy. "Oracle's long history of technology innovation, along with over seven years of relentless engineering and key strategic acquisitions, has enabled Oracle to now feature the most comprehensive cloud offerings in the world. With our focus on simplifying IT for our customers, we have seen tremendous traction for our cloud solutions across sectors, while building a complete cloud ecosystem."

He noted that across the Asia-Pacific, there are numerous examples of "innovative companies exploiting Oracle cloud, including recent examples of Oracle sales cloud at CityWalk and Globetech".

In a global adoption survey conducted last year, it was found that the majority of businesses worldwide have yet to fully integrate their cloud applications across all business functions, Mr Sinha said.

He added that, in Asia, the survey revealed that cloud adoption in Singapore businesses is at 94 per cent, one of the highest in the world when compared to the global average of 71 per cent. However, seven out of 10 of these companies have indicated that the lack of software interoperability and integration between cloud apps and existing company software remain key challenges in cloud deployment.

Apart from these, the lack of skilled labour is also another challenge in successful cloud deployment, he added. According to the survey, 61 per cent of companies in Singapore revealed that their employees do not have the necessary skills to maximise the cloud apps that have been deployed.

He noted that the cloud offers customers a broader choice to consume technology in order to achieve the best RoI (return on investment), leverage capacity on demand, and related innovations.

"It allows customers to fully embrace mobile technologies to maximise productivity, anytime and anywhere. In fact, we have just announced how the Oracle Cloud Marketplace is helping boost sales force adoption with the easy-to-use and intuitive user interface," he said.

Apart from these, cloud is also changing and enhancing business models for Oracle's partner ecosystem, Mr Sinha added. "This means expanding the reach for distribution and providing further flexible choices for business models with Oracle's 400,000 customers; 25,000 Oracle partners; and 15 million community developers to create an ecosystem for shared innovating with cloud."

He added that Oracle enables customers to leverage their existing on-premise IT investment and have it seamlessly integrate and interoperate with their cloud and mobile deployments.

Meeting this challenge highlights Oracle's R&D (research and development) investments in open standards to engineer the layers of the cloud stack to work together and interoperate with on-premise investment.
